Kamala Harris has taken over the reins of power as vice president. Friends and family members of Grant were invited to join in the parade and show off their own unique outfits . After the parade, Grant told USA TODAY that he saw humor as a coping mechanism in the aftermath of Hurricane Ida, which hit New Orleans from August 29 to August 30 . The New Orleans resident also said he hopes the outfits will bring attention to the issue of uncollected garbage in the city . Tiger Woods should have been evaluated for possible signs of impairment before the day he crashed his SUV, experts say.

It is still unclear exactly what led to the crash last week, but authorities are treating the incident as an accident. In a statement, Alex Villanueva, LA County Sheriff, said there was 'no evidence of impairment' in Tiger Woods' SUV. The LA Times quotes him as saying, "We have no cause of the crash as of yet."

In an effort to make the story more dramatic, authorities have tried to make it look like the SUV crashed through a fence and ended up in a wooded area. While the Sheriff's Department acknowledges that there was a fence that was hit in the crash, Woods' car was partially submerged in water and he was found sitting on the ground outside of his SUV a few blocks away, according to the Times.

In the statement, the Sheriff's Department said that the crash was an accident because of what they call 'impairment of consciousness.' That means a driver must not be able to remember what happened to him, according to CNN. The statement even says that the crash was due to "a sudden change in roadway conditions, resulting in a loss of control of the SUV."

The statement also says there is "no cause of the crash as of yet," which again makes it seem as if the incident was completely out of Woods' control and the authorities are just trying to make a dramatic statement that the crash was not intentional.

This is a very unethical way to go about investigating a possible crime. Experts say that if a driver is driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol, they would have a harder time remembering what happened to them. It makes it even more difficult to determine whether or not a person was driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, especially when they were unconscious.

As the Sheriff's Dept. continues to try to make this crash a tragic accident, it does little to help the public. Instead of focusing on what caused the crash and trying to help Tiger Woods and his family deal with the aftermath, the Sheriff's Dept. seems to be focusing on what happened to Tiger's SUV and trying to paint Tiger as the one who caused a crash that he clearly wasn't at fault for.

Experts say they are frustrated with the LA County Sheriff's Department's lack of transparency. They are also upset that there has been little publicity about the case, especially since they say that the lack of transparency is due to authorities' attempts to make this crash seem more dramatic than it actually was.

The Suez Canal is one of the world's most important shipping routes, and will remain so long as there is international trade to be done. The Canal is famous in history for its ability to bring goods from one ocean to the other within a week, even during the Napoleonic Wars of the 19th Century. Now, in 2021, the Suez Canal is the subject of a new development that is likely to have long-term implications for international trade: the $19 billion (Â£13 billion) reconstruction of the canal, which is due to be finished in 2026. The Suez Canal is not the only way to reach Asia. The Strait of Malacca connects the Indian Ocean and Southeast Asia. The best route between the Indian Ocean and Southeast Asia is the Panama Canal. In its heyday, the canal handled more than 1.6 million tonnes of cargo a year. The Panama Canal, on the other hand, is much narrower than the Suez Canal, with a maximum depth of just 4.2 metres (13.7 feet). The Suez Canal runs a width of 2560 metres (9500 feet). The Panama Canal has a maximum depth of 10 metres (32 feet). In 2021, a cargo ship broke through an opening in the wall of the Suez Canal and sank, blocking the entire canal. It is believed that the Ever Given cargo ship ran aground on the west side of the canal, at the Suez Canal Breakwater, which separates the eastern basin from the western basin of the Suez Canal. The Ever Given was originally loaded in South Korea. The Suez Canal is a vital route for trade, but in 2021, the ship Ever Given ran aground and blocked the entire canal for six days (Ever Given ran aground in 2021 and blocked the Suez Canal for six days). It is believed that the ship ran aground on the west side of the canal, the Suez Canal Breakwater, which separates the eastern basin from the western basin of the Suez Canal The canal runs a width of 2560 metres (9500 feet). The Panama Canal has a maximum depth of 32 feet. The Suez Canal was opened in 1869 and handles over 25 million tonnes of cargo a year.

It was one of the most dangerous journeys journalists have ever taken, to Kabul's airport from the Taliban-held capital of Kandahar. The journey was not meant to be a positive one. It was to be a last resort, an escape. And for most Washington Post reporters, it actually was an escape. On August 30, two days after the Taliban took over Kabul, we were given a chance to travel to Qatar on a chartered plane. Washington Post's staff in Kabul had previously been the subject of assault from Taliban gunmen who had tried to kill us twice while we tried to flee Kabul, and I was worried for Aziz Tassal, my daughter and others who were with us. He was one of the first to leave the capital, in a convoy provided by the United States, on August 29. We left Kandahar on a bus, and then took a helicopter to Kabul. On arrival at the Kabul airport on Monday, August 30, we were met by U.S. and Afghan officials and led to a waiting chartered flight to Qatar. When we arrived at the airport in Kabul on Monday August 30, we were met by U.S. and Afghan officials and taken to a waiting chartered flight to Qatar. Aziz Tassal, my daughter and others were beaten up by militants who tried to stop us from leaving Kandahar to return to Kabul, where they had been beaten up. The United States was aware the Taliban were moving to take over Kabul and the situation had become very dangerous. But the U.S. and Afghan governments were just not equipped to provide an evacuation flight. The Taliban were taking the city by force, and there were hundreds of thousands of people trapped inside. We couldn't even get to the airport. So we had to return to Kandahar, where Aziz Tassal was shot several times and injured, where I was beaten up by militants who tried to stop us from leaving Kandahar to return to Kabul, where we had been beaten up. The Biden administration were escalating evacuation plans, but could not provide us with a safe passage.

Facebook and Germany's justice system have come under fire after a prominent German journalist posted political comments to Facebook which were deleted without warning and her account blocked. Germany's election campaign rages on, as the Bundestag holds its last debate before voting, with the Social Democrats in a lead of at least 16 points. In its verdict, Germany's highest court condemned the social network for allegedly breaching European law. Facebook users can now comment on German election debates Facebook bans political posts and posts from users who hate Jews or Muslims More than a million comments and 10 million likes have been posted in less than an hour on the Bundestag debate, which was streamed live on Facebook. Facebook said it had blocked comments on the debate due to a series of hate speech posts that were not content violations. In its verdict, the court added that Facebook's community standards, which prohibit users from posting content that constitutes a direct threat to another person, violated European law. The Federal Court of Justice also condemned Facebook for not offering users a right of appeal against their posts being removed and their accounts being blocked. "The Federal Court of Justice's decision demonstrates that Facebook, as a media company, is responsible towards its users," Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg said in a statement. Facebook was given the power to block users who violated its terms of service in 2008. The German lawyer who filed the case has called the ruling "a victory for free speech". "This is not the first time that we see such an unfolding on Facebook," she added. A family of five was killed when a fire broke out in their Sugar Land, Texas, home over the course of the early hours of Saturday. Three kids and their grandmother were fatally burned in the incident that also left mother and a friend badly injured. Jackie Pham Nguyen, 6, and her mother Le Nguyen, 40, were killed in the Feb. 16 fire at a two-story home. Their older brother, Pham, 2, and their grandmother, Nguyen, 65, also died. They were all asleep in the same room, according to authorities. The woman who filmed the fire heard a gunshot and screaming, but could not reach her friend or her two children. Her friend lived alone at the home. Authorities have yet to confirm the cause of the fire, but are investigating whether it was started accidentally or intentionally. The family, including Loan Le, used the fireplace for heat due to power outages. The mother and her friend were badly burned, with Le Nguyen requiring emergency surgery, according to a release from the fire department. She is in critical condition at an area hospital. The mother has been identified as Loan Le, 40, from Sugar Land, Texas. She has been treated at a local hospital. Her mother was also in the home but was not seriously hurt. Authorities say Le Nguyen was able to evacuate the home with her children but was unable to do so with her friend. The family was asleep in the room when the fire started, authorities said. NEW YORK (Reuters) - Kyle Rittenhouse was acquitted on Wednesday of shooting dead two men and wounding one in a Wisconsin suburb of Kenosha during last year's protests over the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager, a lawyer for the defense said, as Donald Trump's son-in-law attended a prayer vigil at the scene of the deadly attack. The jury deliberated for more than 26 hours before acquitting Rittenhouse in the Kenosha shootings that ignited a national debate over vigilantism and gun rights. The Kenosha suburb is home to about 100,000 people and is considered a stronghold of white supremacists, pro-Trump protesters and gun rights groups. The Wisconsin court heard from more than a dozen witnesses, including video of the night's events, as the defense argued Rittenhouse shot to protect himself after a group of protesters attacked him. Rittenhouse said he shot one person, the second one was shot by an unknown person, while the third man died of wounds incurred in the attack, his lawyers said. Some protesters, including a man wearing a Kenosha flag, waved the American flag as they prayed for Rittenhouse. The Kenosha suburb is considered a stronghold of white supremacists, pro-Trump protesters and gun rights groups Rittenhouse became a national symbol after a series of violent protests erupted last summer in Kenosha, Wisconsin after the police shot unarmed black teenager Jacob Blake.

Congress has not yet passed a major stimulus bill that includes stimulus checks. Patty Murray (D-WA), was released on Monday. It proposes that stimulus checks be issued to Americans for up to two years to help people who have lost their jobs and income due to the coronavirus pandemic. Democrats have not yet agreed on a stimulus bill. They are currently working to pass a bill that includes some funding for coronavirus testing, vaccines, direct payments to Americans, and an extension for unemployment insurance. In the letter, the Senate Democrats propose that the stimulus checks go to Americans for up to two years, beginning in October 2021, if the Congress approves their stimulus bill. They also call on the president to propose a stimulus bill in the first 100 days of his administration.

The analysis is based on state records in the past decade, and we also looked at other states with similar weather, but without the same widespread power outages that occurred in Texas, to see if they had a spike in deaths. Kabul, Afghanistan (CNN) -- As U.S. troops pull out of Afghan in the wake of last week's suicide attack at Kabul airport, the U.S. military is beginning to focus attention on a key part of the Taliban's security plan: recruiting fighters from outside the country to fight in Afghanistan. This strategy would be a dangerous gamble for the U.S. and Afghanistan, but the U.S. military is willing to take that risk to reduce the overall threat of U.S. troops in Afghanistan. U.S.-led forces are trying to stop ISIS-K militants from capturing the rest of the country, but the U.S. is preparing to let ISIS-K, and other militants, move on to threaten Kabul if they think it's safest to do so, said a U.S. official. Karimi appeared on Saturday's show to congratulate ISIS-K for carrying out the airport attack, and to praise the group's leadership for planning the attack and claiming responsibility for it. He added that the Taliban and ISIS-K had the same goal: the destruction of the U.S. presence in Afghanistan.

The next round is expected to be slightly larger than the first, though it will be distributed in a more fragmented way with many states receiving their own version. These payments will be available through December, with future aid discussed in federal budget packages . The state will also be offering $150 per household for those who are struggling to pay for rent, if they qualify. 4. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have released a statement in support of the resumption of the Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) COVID-19 vaccine use. The statement was made after an internal review of safety data on the vaccine, the FDA and the CDC said Monday.

The CDC said Sunday that it would resume using the vaccine in people over the age of 18 after suspending it earlier in the week due to six reports of a rare and potentially serious type of blood clot that can occur with the vaccine.

The announcement came hours after the U.S. and other countries started vaccinating millions of their populations against the coronavirus pandemic.

The FDA's press secretary had earlier told NBC News that a review of safety data had been completed on the Janssen vaccine, and the agency would resume its use. The agency had recommended a pause in use of the vaccine after the initial reports of the clots.

The agency decided to pause use of the vaccine after initial reports of the clots. On Monday, health officials said the CDC will resume its use in adults age 18 and older. They said that six cases of rare, potentially severe blood clots were reported after the people took the vaccine. But they said those clots were unrelated to the Janssen vaccine.

"This decision to suspend use of the Janssen vaccine in the U.S. is based on an internal review of the data, which is consistent with WHO guidance," the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a statement. "This review found no safety concerns with the Janssen vaccine, and concluded that the benefits of the vaccine outweigh the risks."

While the CDC's statement doesn't explicitly say it will resume use of the vaccine, officials said Monday that they believe the CDC's decision "will be similar" to theirs.

On Sunday night, the CDC announced it would suspend its use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. The agency said Sunday that it would resume use of the vaccine in people over the age of 18 after suspending it earlier in the week due to six reports of a rare and potentially serious type of blood clot that can occur with the vaccine. But health officials said the CDC didn't want to rush to resume use of the vaccine because they didn't know yet if the clots were linked to the vaccine.

The Food and Drug Administration has expanded Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 booster eligibility for individuals 16 and 17 years old. The vaccine is authorized for use with the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. The FDA is providing this updated guidance to help health care providers, consumers, and others understand how this decision will impact the safety and effectiveness of this vaccine for 16- and 17-year-olds. As of today, Nov. 29, 2021, individuals 16 and 17 years old will be eligible to receive a booster dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine if they have received a primary dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine at least six months ago. This decision was made based on the available data at that time and is the result of a rigorous review by the FDA's Vaccines and Biological Products Directorate, Vaccine Safety and Technical Enforcement, Immunization Safety and Technical Enforcement, and Vaccines and Related Biological Products Scientific Oversight and Regulatory Affairs. The Vaccines and Biological Products Scientific Oversight and Regulatory Affairs section of the FDA has not received additional data to support this expanded eligibility since the review.

This decision is not a change to the vaccine product label. The manufacturer has confirmed that the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine will still protect against COVID-19.

The FDA will continue to update this guidance when new data becomes available. We encourage all adults and health care professionals to continue taking precautions to prevent the spread of COVID-19, including wearing masks, practicing social distancing, and avoiding crowds.

Mary Trump is the daughter-in-law of Donald Trump and the daughter of his daughter Ivanka Trump.CNN's Chris Cuomo interviewed her at Trump Tower in New York City on Friday. Cuomo: So, Mary, how would Donald feel about prosecutors targeting his children if they could be charged in some way? Mary Trump: Well, Donald Trump is a family man, and I think he would not look at it that way at all. If he did that, I think he'd think they were taking a hit to their benefit. And I don't know if he would be that forgiving of it. Cuomo: So, you believe that your father would expect his children to take a hit to his benefit? Mary Trump: No, I think that he would look at it more as a sacrifice. He would be relieved to see the children have a happy life. Now, I don't know if he would be that forgiving of it. Joint Chiefs of Staff Statement: We will always be ready to defend the U.S. Constitution

Washington, D.C., January 12, 2021

The United States and its military will always be ready to defend the U.S. Constitution. We condemn the violent attack on the U.S. Capitol on January 6 and mourn the loss of lives and property that ensued. The Joint Chiefs reaffirm that those who break the law and threaten the rule of law are not to be allowed to succeed.

President Biden has set out his agenda for the first 100 days of his presidency. He has pledged to restore U.S. supremacy by building a better, more diverse, more equal society. The Joint Chiefs of Staff have expressed their support for this important goal. The U.S. Constitution protects the most basic rights of every human being by setting limits on the authority of government. The U.S. Constitution gives each citizen a right to freedom of expression, freedom of religion, freedom of association, equal protection of the law, and due process of the law. The U.S. Constitution is the backbone of American democracy and the United States military is dedicated to upholding the Constitution. While the joint chiefs did not discuss the Biden-Electoral College transition, they made clear that they are committed to defending the rule of law. In addition, the joint chiefs condemned violence on January 6. They described the Capitol breach as a direct assault on Congress, the Capitol, and the rule of law. The Joint Chiefs also condemned the violent attack on the United States Supreme Court. They are committed to a peaceful transfer of power.

Vistra Corp. (NYSE:VIS) issued a new estimate for the cost of a recent winter storm Uri, which hit the Midwest earlier this year. The energy company raised the February estimate from $900 million to $1.3 billion, or an increase of 1,000 per cent. The winter storm Uri was the most severe to hit the Midwest in 25 years, the company said in a regulatory filing. The storm cost Vistra approximately $1.6 billion in January, when it raised that estimate to $1.3 billion, according to a regulatory filing. Vistra also revised its outlook for its 2021 EBITDA and free cash flow guidance. The company said it expects 2021 to see a revenue increase in the low single-digits, with EBITDA and free cash flow falling into the range of $1,475-$1,875 million and $200-$600 million respectively. In a regulatory filing, Vistra said its new estimate for the cost of the winter storm Uri had been calculated using a conservative approach based on the potential for additional legal, regulatory and accounting challenges, the Wall Street Journal reports. "We remain encouraged about the opportunities for growth."

Bose Corporation, maker of headphones and other audio equipment, says it has been the victim of a sophisticated cyber assault by a group of hackers that appears to have stolen personal data of more than 60,000 clients and employees. Authorities in New Hampshire were notified of the cyberattack on Friday, according to Bose. The data reportedly includes salaries, social security numbers and the names of clients. Ransomware attack highlights the ongoing national issue with ransomware attacks affecting various sectors . Hundreds of thousands of headphones were affected by a ransomware attack last year . Cybercriminals have taken a total of $330,000 in Bitcoin ransom payments . Bose claims that the attack began in early March this year . Bose says that the cyberattack appears to have involved social security numbers for former employees of the New Hampshire-based company . The company said that they had detected an exfiltration in April . The company said they were contacted by local authorities last Friday and the data was taken to a data recovery facility . They now say that no evidence had been found of the data having been sold on the dark web . The company believes that not all of the data has been recovered .

President Biden's cybersecurity executive order could lead to federal cybersecurity funding, but how much of a threat does that pose to the energy sector? By Laura Hillenbrand, Roll Call Staff Writers, and John Schmierer, Roll Call. As cybersecurity threats grow in the U.S., President Joe Biden and his administration are taking the lead in addressing them. That's part of a bigger picture: A series of incidents since 2015 have put a spotlight on the vulnerability of the American economy to cyberattacks. Back in 2015, a phishing email sent to nearly 200,000 companies around the world contained ransomware. In 2018, ransomware attacks in the U.S. led to the closure of the SolarWinds network, which resulted in the disclosure of the U.S. government's cybersecurity flaws. Last year, the US government acknowledged for the first time that it had been breached in at least one instance by a foreign nation. In a statement last month, the US government acknowledged that it was being "cyber-attacked" by Russia. "In order to take a more proactive approach to addressing these challenges," Biden said, "I am issuing an executive order to improve the federal government's cybersecurity management." Biden has not yet specified how he plans to change the way the government manages security. He did say that the executive order would be "a step forward." But Biden has not been the only administration to issue cybersecurity directives. In 2015, President Barack Obama issued a cybersecurity executive order, which called on the government to adopt cybersecurity best practices. In addition, the U.S. has established a cybersecurity council chaired by FBI Director Christopher Wray. The Trump administration issued a cybersecurity directive in 2018, and in December, it issued a white... Roll call.com: Joe Biden's new cybersecurity executive order could boost the energy sector . Cyber-security threats to America's energy sector are growing in the U.S., according to a report . President Biden is seeking federal funds to fund cybersecurity research . Biden and some energy industry executives say the executive order is not enough to stem cyber-threats .

HARRISONBURG, Michigan (AP) — A 15-year-old boy accused of plotting to kill four people at a high school in his hometown has been charged with 24 crimes, including terrorism, and has been accused of killing one person and injuring two others in the shooting, authorities said Thursday. Ethan Crumbley, the suspect, is being held without bond after his arrest in suburban Michigan Thursday night. Austin Witt, the son of the school's principal, said the shooting victim's name was "Tate Myre."

Ethan Crumbley has been charged with 24 crimes including murder and terrorism, including plotting to kill four people in a Michigan high school shooting, authorities said Thursday night. (CBS News via AP)

Investigators found digital evidence suggesting Crumbley planned the attack, including a video and journal detailing his intent, police said.

Crumbley's father, Mark, told the AP that he had heard of his son's case before he was arrested Thursday night. He said that he was not aware of his son's involvement with the shooting.

Mark said he had not talked with his son in some time because of tensions between their families. He said he was shocked that his son would do something like this. Crumbley has been charged with murder, kidnapping, kidnapping with intent to kill or maim, voluntary manslaughter, and more, and authorities say he planned to kill four people.

He also has been accused of threatening a police officer who shot him during a confrontation a few days before the shooting.

Ethan Crumbley, the suspect, was arrested Thursday night and is being held without bond.

Authorities also say they found a video that appears to show Crumbley planning the attack, which was seen by a school administrator. The video showed Crumbley with a loaded gun in his hand.

Kelsee Lainhart's recovery journey has taken her from Walter Reed to Shirley Ryan AbilityLab in Chicago. She survived the Kabul Airport attack on Aug. 26 . Today, she's a role model in the fight against paralysis . Lainhart was paralyzed on her left side after the attack . Here, she shares her message of hope and empowerment to others who have been similarly affected . (CNN) -- "I can't see, I can't move, I can't speak," Lainhart told me, her voice trembling in her throat. "I can't control my muscles and I can't breathe." Lainhart was sitting on a chair in the middle of a living room in Kabul. She had been shot in the chest during the Aug. 26 bombing of the U.S. Embassy, which left 11 U.S. service members dead and wounding more than a dozen people. Thirteen service members from the U.S. were later killed in the attack, which began when an attack vehicle parked outside the Embassy opened fire, according to U.S. officials. A bomb exploded outside the entrance to the Embassy, injuring at least five people, including several U.S. service members, and killing a Taliban fighter, U.S. officials said. A few days later, Lainhart, who had been injured in the attack, was airlifted to Walter Reed Air Force Base, where she spent several months recovering. She was eventually discharged after undergoing surgery at Walter Reed. She was discharged from the military on Sept. 30 and transferred to Chicago-based Shirley Ryan AbilityLab, which houses patients with paralysis who are recovering from severe brain injuries. "I am not an easy person to talk to," she said. "I am difficult and I can be mean," she said. "I know that I am weak and that I may not recover. I am just not going to hold it in for long. And that's what I want to give to other people who are in the same situation." Lainhart added that she is a role model in the fight against paralysis, which continues to strike thousands of U.S. service members who return home. "Right now, I'm all about giving back and I want to empower other people to want to do the same," she said. "I want to inspire them." Lainhart, 24, spoke to CNN from her home in Chicago. The attack at the Embassy took place after years of fighting and... After two surgeries, Kelsee Lainhart, from Chicago, has recovered and now is role model in U.S. military struggle against paralysis . Lainhart survived the Aug. 26 attack on the U.S. Embassy during the final days of U.S. involvement in Afghanistan .

In fact, El Paso's experience was the most favorable of all the U.S. cities affected by the storm. El Paso Electric spent millions on winterizing its facilities, including the construction of the Montana Power Station with dual-fuel capability, and its connection to the Western Interconnection grid. El Paso was one of the few U.S. cities, along with Portland, Oregon, to avoid major power failures during the storm, according to FEMA.

The last Canadian troops left Afghanistan on Thursday, hours before an attack at Kabul airport killed 11 U.S. marines and one Canadian navy medic. Canada's national security minister confirmed that all Canadians involved in the mission have been accounted for and are safe. The attack at the airport came as part of a series of attacks across the country, with the Taliban claiming responsibility for some of them, including Friday's suicide bomb attack in Kabul. The US has confirmed that 11 of its troops were killed, but cannot confirm if the attack was carried out by U.S. troops, or by the Taliban.

The US-led military campaign against the Taliban ended with the mission's deadline for withdrawal earlier this month, with a total of 13,500 troops leaving Afghanistan by 31 August.

The Canadian Forces confirmed all Canadian military personnel were accounted for and safe following the mission's deadline.

According to official sources, the last Canadian forces left Afghanistan around 20:00 local time (15:00 GMT) on Thursday, while U.S. and NATO forces left Afghanistan a few hours later on Thursday and Friday morning, as part of the joint withdrawal plan.

As the Canadian forces were leaving, Canadians were returning home to the airport, where they were greeted by US and NATO troops.

Earlier, the United States said that a suicide bomb had hit Kabul airport, killing 11 U.S. marines and one Canadian navy medic.

"The U.S. military has deployed additional forces to secure the airport," the Pentagon said in a statement.

Senate Democrats and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer called on the Senate GOP to vote in favor of $2,000 stimulus checks . The Senate Minority Leader urged Republicans to support the increase . The House passed a $2000 bill last week . Trump had criticized the $600 direct payments as far too low for the amount of assistance . The House voted to increase the payment to $2000 and passed the bill . Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., spoke to the Senate floor on Wednesday as Senate Democrats pushed to secure a Senate vote on the stimulus checks increase to $2,000 . Sanders called on the Senate Republicans not to block the vote, but that the fight wasn't over . The House of Representatives passed the bill to increase payments from $600 to $2000 last week after the President Trump urged for the higher amount . Trump criticized the $600 direct payments and said they were too low for the amount of assistance provided . Sen. Lindsey Graham called on senators to reject the House legislation because it was not signed by the president . The Senate Republicans are unlikely to take up the bill, and it's unclear if it will be approved in the Senate . (CNN) -- House of Representatives Sen. Chuck Schumer and Sen. Bernie Sanders pushed unsuccessfully for a Senate vote on Tuesday on the increase in stimulus payments to $2,000. Senate Republicans opposed the increase to the $600 direct payments initially negotiated by the House. "The Senate Republicans have blocked the House of Representatives from addressing the needs of our families," said Sanders, who is seeking to become the Democratic Party's presidential candidate in 2020. "They should be the party of the middle class, not the party of Wall Street." "We are here tonight to send a message to Wall Street that they have the support of the majority of the American people," Schumer said. "I urge the Senate Republicans to join us and do the right thing." House of Representatives Sen. Mark Warner, R-Virginia, called for the Senate Republicans to vote in favor of the measure, saying the Senate would not have passed the bill without the help of the House. Senate Republicans have been reluctant to vote on measures from the House of Representatives. Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., said that the Senate Democrats were trying to "break the rules" by blocking a bill from the House of Representatives. Senate Republicans said Tuesday they would not pass the Senate bill without the help of the House of Representatives, so the Senate Democrats would have to bring it up again in 2020. The Senate passed the first $600 stimulus checks on Sunday. The House of Representatives approved it last week, and President Trump signed it into law a day later as part of the first coronavirus relief bill.

There's been speculation that Prince Harry and his wife Meghan might not have wanted their son, Prince Archie, to be called Earl of Dumbarton, despite the Royal Family's insistence that he has a right to it - but what is the real reason behind the decision? Andrew Morton, who has written about Prince Harry and the Duchess of Sussex for many years, has revealed why he believes they might have opted not to name their son after the town in Scotland.

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are not the only royals to have a son named after a town - the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's son, Prince Louis also had his name taken from Dumbarton.

Royal biographer Andrew Morton (pictured) suggests that Harry and Meghan were concerned that giving their son a Scottish town name might lead to mockery and bullying.

Mr Morton told the Daily Mirror newspaper: 'It wasn't just the Scottish town, it was the fact they had a Scottish name - Archie.'

He said: 'The fact that he was called Archie was a big factor in that.'

Mr Morton said Harry and Meghan feared Archie would be mocked for being named Earl of Dumbarton - because of the word 'dumb'

Australian media giants Google and Facebook are threatening to limit some of their services in Australia if a digital news code is passed into law by the Australian government next month. The Australian Prime Minister has refused to respond to the threats and insisted his government will not bow to threats from tech giants. The Australian government's Digital News Code is currently being considered by a Senate committee and is expected to be passed in the next few months. The Digital News Code requires digital platforms such as Google, Facebook and Twitter to pay the news media for the content they publish on their websites, and to provide Australians with a way to opt-out of this service. Google says the code could force it to limit services in Australia if it is passed. Facebook has not commented on the Digital News Code, which it has described as "unprecedented and unconscionable". Google has 19 million Australians users, while Facebook users number in the millions. Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, and WhatsApp all experienced outages for some users on Thursday afternoon . Users began reporting issues around 2 p.m. ET, according to DownDetector.com . The outage affected Messenger, Workplace Chat, and Instagram DMs . Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the issue was fixed by the end of the day . (CNN)Facebook and its messaging apps experienced an outage on Thursday afternoon, which forced millions of users to find new ways to communicate. The outage began around 2 p.m., reported the DownDetector.com website, according to users around the world, and the outage affected Facebook Messenger, Workplace Chat, and Instagram Direct Messages. The outage, which affected the social network's Instagram, Messenger and WhatsApp, was reported to begin around 2 p.m., according to DownDetector.com users around the world, as well as at the time of this writing. The company acknowledged the issue, saying work was underway to resolve the issues. Facebook's head of Messenger, Chris Cox, said the problem "was corrected by the end of the day" in a post on Facebook's blog. "We're taking this opportunity to thank all of you who have reached out to support us," he said. The outage came as WhatsApp also experienced issues. On Twitter, the app's chief executive said the issue had been resolved "over the past few hours" and thanked users for their patience. The company also acknowledged the problem, which affected the social network's Instagram, Messenger and WhatsApp, and said work was underway to resolve the issues. The issue was reported to begin around 2 p.m., the same time as the Facebook and Instagram outage, according to DownDetector.com users around the world, as well as at the time of this writing.

President Donald Trump was impeached last week for his role in the US Capitol riot that left five dead and hundreds of arrested. Trump supporters stormed the building last week and took control for several hours. It was not the first time Trump supporters had stormed the Capitol. Trump supporters in riot at US Capitol . The first impeachment trial took place against Trump last year and was dismissed. The impeachment process is political, not legal, meaning Congress can determine guilt without proof of legal culpability. Trump supporters stormed the Capitol on 6 January, forcing Trump's hand. The US House of Representatives is set to debate an article of impeachment against President Donald Trump, accusing him of inciting violence against the US government. Trump's urging of his supporters to "fight" before the riot is central to the accusation. Congress has to vote on whether Trump should be removed from office before the end of his term. 57 percent of Americans want Trump to remain in office after January 20, and 57 percent believe he should remain in office, while 32 percent want Trump removed from power.

Research shows that right-leaning tweets have more prominence on Twitter's Home timeline than left-wing ones, according to a new study.

Twitter's Home timeline shows the most retweets by people who follow a given account.

The new study found that in six out of seven countries, right-leaning tweets were more amplified than left-leaning ones. For example, in both Canada and the UK, right-leaning tweets were more than twice as likely to be retweeted than left-wing tweets. Twitter said that it is unclear why its algorithm produced these results.

The study also found that political content on Twitter was more likely to be amplified on Twitter's Home timeline than through a chronological timeline. According to Twitter, the company does not control the timing of when content is shared on the Home timeline and is unable to ensure that the chronological timeline will not be affected.

Twitter's study looked at tweets from elected officials in seven countries including the U.S., U.K., Canada, Brazil, Russia, Germany, and Japan. The researchers found that political tweets were more likely to be retweeted when they appeared on the Home timeline rather than through the chronological timeline. In the U.S., for example, right-leaning tweets from elected officials were more than twice as likely to be retweeted on Twitter's Home timeline compared to left-leaning tweets. In the UK, right-leaning tweets from the UK Prime Minister were more than 10 times as likely to be retweeted on Twitter's Home timeline compared to left-leaning tweets.

Racism in American policing is a system of racial control and exploitation, a new column from former Guardian journalist David Leonhardt explains in a Washington Post opinion piece. Exploiting the system of racial control and exploitation that exists at the heart of American policing, Derek Chauvin and his fellow officers racially discriminated against unarmed black men in Minneapolis. But their actions did not justify killing them and they will not be pardoned.

Chauvin's conviction signals that the United States is moving in new directions. It is time to end the endless cycle of racism, white supremacy and policing that is killing tens of thousands of black and brown Americans each year.

Read David Leonhardt's full column here

Even without racial bias, policing won't solve the problems of inequality and exploitation. One of the many tragedies of the United States has been that people have not considered policing as a system of racial discrimination.

The system works as follows. We are all equally entitled to the freedom of movement under the rule of law. That is the cornerstone of our democracy. In other words, when we are at the mercy of a police officer who decides whether we can go to the grocery store or a convenience store, it is not a free society.

For decades, police, many of whom were white, discriminated and exploited black and brown people in the name of protecting the public. The result is that Americans are at the mercy of the police and they depend on them for access to basic human needs.

At a time when we need to focus the anger about the killing of George Floyd at the hands of a police officer on racism, the system of racial control and exploitation at the heart of American policing should also be considered. This is not a problem of George Floyd's death alone. It is a system that benefits white supremacists and racists, but harms blacks and brown people.

But most importantly, the system of racial control and exploitation creates a cycle of violence that lasts many years. By killing unarmed black people in the name of protecting the public, white supremacists are creating a vicious cycle of revenge. The result is that many black and brown men and women are killed by police in the same way that George Floyd was killed.

Chauvin's conviction signals that the United States is moving in new directions. It is time to end the endless cycle of racism, white supremacy, and policing that is killing tens of thousands of black and brown Americans each year.

Kabul's airport is secure after an ISIS-K suicide bomber attacked the facility last week, officials said Wednesday, but the struggle to secure it will likely continue, particularly as the Taliban continue to move in on the city and its perimeter.

The attack also highlighted how quickly insurgents could strike in the final days of the US withdrawal from Afghanistan, officials said.

The Taliban gained control of the area around the airport and released several prisoners, including members of ISIS-K, when they seized Parwan prison at Bagram air base and Pul-e-Charkhi prison near Kabul.

A US official said the operation to bring the suicide bomber back from the prison to Afghanistan "has taken longer than expected."

The identity of the bomber was confirmed by two US officials and Rep. Ken Calvert, the Democrat who is chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee.

"These attacks show that the Taliban can be very dangerous and very disruptive," Rep. Calvert said.

Police in western Wyoming say a woman in her 20s who vanished while on a cross-country road trip last week has been found unharmed. Gabrielle Petito was traveling in a white Ford Transit van with her boyfriend in western Wyoming, when he got out to use the bathroom, authorities said. Her mother said the couple had planned to reach Portland, Oregon, in October. Petito and her boyfriend, 22-year-old Thomas Hicks, were traveling together in a 2012 Ford Transit van. Petito had been traveling with her boyfriend in a 2012 Ford Transit van . She was last seen at a rest area shortly after leaving the main road in Wyoming on August 30 . Police say she has been unharmed but is being treated as a missing person . Her mother, Nicole Schmidt, said she is concerned that her daughter may have been abducted . Perrysburg police are seeking Thomas Hicks on suspicion of first-degree kidnapping, kidnapping with intent to rape and kidnapping with intent to commit rape .

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has sent out nearly 1.4 billion stimulus checks since March, the last payment date being May 12, 2020. This is a feat that normally takes months, even years. Here, we look at the four ways the IRS processed the payments in the last four months, and how things are likely to go in the next few weeks. The IRS sent over 165 million stimulus checks since March, including more than 460,000 plus-up payments . The agency processed the checks in a variety of ways, including direct deposit and the mail . The Internal Revenue Service prioritized individuals who filed their 2019 or 2020 tax returns and has vetted payment data for government benefit recipients, including Social Security beneficiaries, IRS spokeswoman Kathy Yee said in a statement . Image copyright Getty Images Image caption The agency processed the checks in a variety of ways . Some checks were sent through direct deposit and others were mailed . The agency prioritized individuals who filed their 2019 or 2020 tax returns . Nearly half of the new payments were sent through direct deposit and the rest were mailed through checks or pre-paid debit cards .

A CNN journalist has been reporting from Louisiana as Hurricane Ida grinds through the South and East coasts of the United States and its first confirmed fatality has been reported on the front page of the website. Dennis Duplessis, 58, of Gonzales, Louisiana was struck by a tree during the storm and his death was confirmed as the first on the ground in the aftermath of the storm. Duplessis' death marks the first confirmed fatality from Hurricane Ida, with the storm claiming dozens of lives and causing widespread destruction across Louisiana and Texas in the Gulf of Mexico and Mississippi in the Gulf of Mexico . Volunteers from nearby churches helped to clear the fallen tree from Duplessis' front yard . The death comes as officials are struggling to assess the damage caused by the hurricane . Hurricane Ida is the most powerful hurricane to ever hit the New Orleans region since the hurricane ravaged Katrina in 2005 which killed more than 3,000 people . Hurricane Ida is also the most powerful hurricane to hit Texas since Ivan in 1991 when it was a Category 5 storm .

If you were working on 'Saturday Night Live', you'd know how to stay safe and be a team player - not to mention have the ability to joke about things that happen on the set while they are still happening on the set. This, however, was not what happened with the film 'Rust'. The shooting death of Cinematographer Halyna Hutchins by Alec Baldwin on Christmas Day 2017 is not just a personal tragedy for Baldwin; it was a tragedy for the entire filmmaking community and for those who worked on the film. While the shooting was not intentional, it was an unacceptable accident, and as a Union Prop Master who has worked at SNL for more than 20 years, I know the film industry better than anyone. Baldwin's lack of diligence and disrespect for other people and for a job can be found in countless other movies and in countless other jobs. I am writing to draw attention to the conditions surrounding the shooting and the lack of attention given to safety and team cohesiveness before the shooting even started. The last time I was on the set of 'Rust', which was shot on the same day as the shooting, we were lucky to get out without being injured and the day was full of fun, and to my knowledge other members of SNL, the cast, crew, and other filmmakers in the area were having a great time as well. I am a union prop master with a background in film and television production for 20 years and have worked in some of the most challenging, dangerous and stressful jobs in the business - I know the value of staying safe and feeling empowered as a team. Roughly 15 minutes after we left the set of 'Rust', we heard news that a shooting was taking place at the set of the film. Before I knew it, I heard about the injuries sustained by the director Joel Souza and Cinematographer Halyna Hutchins. We all knew that Alec Baldwin was drunk, and we were all shocked and saddened by what happened to this young man, who was supposed to be responsible for the safety of everyone in the film, including himself. A few days later, it was revealed that there were more than 12 rounds of bullets that Alec... The union prop master wrote to CNN about the shooting incident involving Alec Baldwin on the set of 'Rust', which killed Cinematographer Halyna Hutchins, and the safety protocols used on 'Saturday Night Live'.

Michigan teachers are grieving and at risk of losing their jobs over the mass shooting at Oxford High School in Ann Arbor on Nov. 30.

They are tired, frustrated, and angry, because the level of gun violence in their schools continues to outpace their ability to keep students safe.

In the wake of the shooting, many schools across the state have had to suspend classes and shut the doors indefinitely.

Teachers from across the state have written to the governor, asking for help.

"I don't know what my students are going to do if I'm not in class," says Mary Hart, a history teacher in Oakland Park, Michigan. "If they have to go to school tomorrow, they're going to be like, 'Where did I get off?'"

Across Michigan, schools have been on the brink of closing or suspending classes indefinitely, with no sign of a threat. In some areas, teachers are reporting their students are so fearful they are asking about procedures like locking doors.

Teachers across Michigan are worried that they may lose their jobs. "This is the most dangerous job I ever had." says one woman in the Ann Arbor area. "I don't want to lose my students," she says.

On Wednesday, hundreds of teachers, students, and parents marched in Ann Arbor, calling on the governor to do more to keep schools safe. On Thursday, more than 100,000 people in the state signed an online petition urging Michigan's secretary of education to act.

Why is it so hard for schools in Michigan to keep kids safe?

There has been a string of school shootings across the state, including in Ann Arbor and Plymouth-Canton Community Schools, where the Nov. 30 shooting at Oxford High School took place. This is the second high school shooting in less than a month to take place in Plymouth-Canton Community Schools. The school is located in East Lansing.

This is just a sampling of the shootings Michigan has seen in recent years.

The state is home to nearly 3,000 schools across all 50 states. That makes it the most densely populated school system in the country. That also means that nearly 13,000 schools have had to suspend classes, according to school officials. That's about every third school in the state.

JBS said the attack by the hackers, which also targeted its servers in Australia, was conducted by a group based in Russia, which was not affiliated with the US government, and that the group had not been identified. The attack came after JBS began accepting Bitcoin as a payment for its products, following a similar move by the retailer Costco earlier this year. The lack of state honors for Powell was a clear reminder of how divided the country remains over the past decade. He was one of the most revered military figures of his time, and a great statesman. Still, his legacy and those of others like him are rarely remembered with a high state funeral in this country. This is especially noticeable in the current moment, during a pandemic and a time of social unrest. In the wake of Colin Powell's funeral, here are three things we need more of in the U.S.: Public funerals. By all accounts, Colin Powell's coffin was brought to Washington National Cathedral on a private plane, following his death from complications of covid-19. While it might have seemed an odd way to transport a former Secretary of State's casket, this was the only way to honor Powell's wishes, according to those who knew him. In many ways, this was a reflection on the division in the U.S. While a private funeral can be a good option for families, it is especially important that a public funeral be given to someone of Colin Powell's stature, so that the world can reflect on his achievements. The post-WWII United States is marked by what some consider to be a division between "us" and "them." When the civil rights movement and the Great Migration ended segregation, Americans were united, and the country seemed headed toward a bright future. Over the past several decades, however, Americans have increasingly been torn up over divisive issues such as race, class, gender, and religion. Since the 1950s, Americans have not had a funeral state of their own. While Powell was a great statesman and great military leader, this is not a time for reflection and national healing. Powell's body is currently lying in state for seven days at the Washington National Cathedral, which was his alma mater. After that time, his family will return the casket to Florida to lay him to rest at Camp David, where he had previously spent much of his last days. The casket will be on display during his final resting place at Camp David for seven days. During that time, the nation will reflect on Powell's contributions to the country and to the United States. Over the last three weeks, Americans have protested against police brutality and police violence against Black people. The U.S. has ended its military campaign in Afghanistan, but what will this mean for women in Afghanistan in the months and years after? This is what some women are worried about, according to this week's story by CNN's Vanessa Been. Rashida Yasin writes from Kabul that for some women, the return of the Taliban to power is a bad thing. Here's why: It will be hard to make progress if there is no support of women - and there isn't much if the Taliban doesn't take them seriously, she says. In Herat, dozens of women have staged a protest demanding equal rights and equal opportunities - and there are calls for more similar protests in Kabul. Here is some of Vanessa Been's other stories this week: 1. This week's report from Afghanistan shows that as the U.S. pulls out, there are signs of life on the ground that could signal a positive turn for women . 2. Some fear that the Taliban's promise of a better future for women will be hollow . 3. Other women say the Taliban is not going to allow for equal rights in the near future . 4. Many women in the country have also suffered the devastation of war . The Afghan capital of Kabul is beginning to see signs of life returning after American troops pulled out. The airport and a hospital have reopened. But the Taliban is also back in power and some women are worried that the return could be a bad thing. They fear they will not have equal rights, especially in the new cabinet. And some say the Taliban is not going to allow equal rights in the near future. Women from Herat in western Afghanistan have staged a protest demanding equal rights, equal opportunities, and access to basic services. They want to work and send their sons to school. "I want women to be included in the government so the government can do something for women," she tells CNN. "I am a woman and I want to go to school, work and send my sons to school. I want a good life for my sons." She says she hopes the government will change soon. The Taliban's previous rule in the late 1990s was marked by severe oppression, particularly towards women. Many were barred from working or attending school. And in 2000, the Taliban banned women from driving. The government later relaxed the ban. Many now drive, but there are still restrictions. The U.S. Embassy has said that it continues to urge the Afghan government to ensure women's rights are not eroded after the U.S. withdraws. Experts from Qatar and Turkey are working to reopen Kabul airport after the U.S. withdrawal. There are calls for similar protests in Kabul, where many women are waiting for the airport to open.

Who were some of the key figures in American politics during the George W. Bush presidency? The former president has died aged 90, after a long and illustrious political career which included a controversial return to politics, leading to a second term as US President and then as Governor of Texas. Here we look at the key figures in American politics during his presidency and how he was viewed by his fellow politicians. President George W. Bush was one of the most powerful figures in American politics during the George W. Bush presidency, but was controversially returned to politics in 2006 following his first term in office. He was elected Governor of Texas in 2001 to take over from Republican former Governor Dick Cheney, and was reelected to the governorship in 2006. Bush's controversial return to politics led to the first term as US President after he won election in 2004, after the Republican Party lost power to the Democrats. This was followed by a second term as US President in which he focused on bringing the country out of the financial crisis of 2007/8 and becoming a global force for peace and stability. The Republican Party lost control of the US Senate in 2010 to the Democrats, leading to a run-off election where Republican Senator John McCain was defeated. He led the Republican party to the 2012 elections and was elected President again, which was the first time in the party's history that the party had held power in the executive branch for more than four years. After the Iraq War, President Bush advocated for further military action, and took a leading role in the fight against terrorism and the War on Terror. He led the fight against terrorism until 2003, when he announced he would not seek re-election. He retired to painting after the Iraq War and was knighted in 2008 for services to his country, and was awarded the Medal of Honor for his actions during the... Bush first ran for US President in the 1988 election but failed to win. He won election as Governor of Texas in 2001 to become the first Republican to hold the office, following his election as Governor of the state in a special race in 2000. He was reelected to the governorship in 2006 and in 2010 won a third term, finishing his first term as governor in 2013 with the highest approval rating in Texas history. He is the second most popular governor in US history behind Democrat Bill Clinton and was the highest paid elected official in Texas history. President Bush led the Republican Party to re-election in 2012 and was elected for a record second term in 2014. He was re-elected to a third term in the 2016 elections. The former president was elected to the Senate from Texas in 1998 and served until 2010. He was also elected to the US House of Representatives in 1986.

Statement on vaccination of children and adolescents against COVID-19 issued on 23 December 2020 by Dr. Soumya Swaminathan, Director-General of the World Health Organization, Director General of the United Nations Children's Fund, on behalf of the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) The COVID-19 pandemic is ongoing, with cases continuing to rise in many countries. At the same time, vaccination against COVID-19 is progressing in many countries. Vaccination will help to halt the spread of the disease and save lives. The best way to protect yourself and your family is to get vaccinated. The greatest burden of COVID-19 remains among older persons and those with comorbidities. WHO prioritizes vaccination for those two populations. Children and adolescents generally experience milder symptoms of COVID-19 compared to adults. Children under the age of five years have a higher risk of diseases with symptoms similar to COVID-19. Children and adolescents can experience 'long COVID-19' and a rare hyperinflammatory syndrome post-infection. Vaccinated children have a lower risk of severe complications such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and severe acute lower respiratory syndrome (Sars). The vaccination of children is a public health priority and should be encouraged by all governments and all relevant stakeholders, including the World Health Organization, UNICEF, and other partners. In this context, the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) are making the following statements: The greatest burden of COVID-19 remains among older persons and those with comorbidities. Children under the age of five years have a higher risk of diseases with symptoms similar to COVID-19. The Taliban seized control over the Afghan capital, Kabul, on Aug. 15, marking the end of nearly two months' rapid offensive across the country . Across the globe, many were shocked by the Taliban's apparent victory in a country that U.S. and international forces had been fighting against for nearly 15 years . But a U.S. administration that has been struggling with the fallout of its withdrawal from the country has promised that Americans will not tolerate the return of U.S. forces to Afghan soil as a result of the offensive . The Taliban had been engaged in an offensive against the Afghan government forces across the country since June 1 . The Taliban claimed they had seized Kabul on Aug. 15 . It was the culmination of several weeks of fighting that saw Taliban forces advance as far east as Uruzgan Province and as far west as Kandahar Province . The Taliban took over control of Kabul on Aug. 15, according to their official website . Taliban militants captured Kabul, the Afghan capital, on Aug. 15, the Taliban announced on their official website . It marked the end of nearly two months' rapid offensive the insurgents launched against the Afghans across the country . The Taliban gained control of Kabul in a series of waves that began as far east as Uruzgan Province and as far west as Kandahar Province . The militants took over control of several cities and towns throughout the country earlier in the month . Many of the towns and cities that were taken over quickly were in the province of Helmand, which borders Pakistan . The insurgents claimed that the fall of Kabul marked the end of their offensive against the Afghan government . The U.S. and international forces have been fighting the Taliban for nearly 15 years . In June, the U.S. announced that it would withdraw all U.S. forces from the country by the end of the year . President Joe Biden addressed the fallout of his administration's withdrawal on Aug. 17, amid global criticism . Taliban spokeswoman, Zabihullah Mujahid, promised respect for women's rights and no reprisals in a press conference . On Friday, Donald Trump and former President Donald Trump announced that they were launching criminal proceedings against each other over allegations of obstruction of justice, fraud, tax evasion and bribery. President Trump, during an impromptu news conference at the White House, said that Donald Trump's former lawyer had asked him about witness testimony, allegedly in the form of money. Mr Trump's statement also included allegations of a conspiracy to undermine the integrity of the 2020 presidential election, and a call for new elections to fix the problem of election fraud. The announcement came on the heels of Mr Trump's firing of his own lawyer, Michael Cohen, for lying to Congress about payments to women who said that he had sex with them. The move has been described as the latest development in a saga of allegations against Mr Trump that began in 2016 and has left him on the defensive. On Tuesday, the House of Representatives impeached Mr Trump for the second time in the history of the U.S. Senate. Donald Trump's impeachment trial could be the end of a political career - but legal experts say an officeholder can be tried after they leave office, and an impeachment does not signal the end of a political career. A nurse fears Texas will lift the state mandate to wear a face mask outside of a home. The US has seen the steepest decline in Covid cases in months and some experts say the states are taking too long to lift restrictions. However, Texas has been slow to take action and has already seen a return of cases from the spring's surge.

Brittany Smart, an ICU nurse from San Antonio, Texas, has said that Texas should lift restrictions so that services can be better protected against Covid-19 cases and staff can better care for those recovering from the disease.

As recently as this week, Smart warned that the state was on the verge of returning to the spike of cases seen earlier in the pandemic.

In this video interview with CNN, Smart expresses fear and exhaustion due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and believes the state should lift restrictions.

You may also want to watch:

What's happening in Texas Texas governor Greg Abbott has not said whether he will lift the state mandate on masks. This is one of the areas where he and his administration have been divided in recent weeks.

The state will be one of several to see the increase in Covid-19 cases in the coming weeks, experts say, as it has not lifted restrictions on restaurants and other businesses, and masks are only required in some circumstances.

While some of the highest-ranked health officials have warned of the dangers of lifting restrictions in Texas too early, Texas has remained one of the last states to lift its restrictions.

In fact, two of the state's six regions have already seen a spike in cases due to the current spike in cases across the state.

The spike started in late December after widespread vaccination, and has seen cases in the city of Dallas, which is part of region six, return to what was seen earlier in the pandemic.

Texas saw over 65,000 cases over the weekend and the state has now averaged over 65,000 cases daily for the last week, according to the CDC.

"Just because the vaccine is in your arm, the vaccine is not in your head," Smart said in her interview with CNN. "We've lost too many people."

With the second and third stimulus checks being sent out to millions of Americans, Forbes has been looking at how people are spending their money. While 75% of recipients use the first stimulus check for basic needs, the next two rounds have largely been spent savings or paying debt. The second round was sent out to all Americans on July 3 and the third was sent out to those who were not eligible for either of the previous checks. People have been using the checks to do the following: People who were ineligible for the first or second stimulus checks are now able to apply for the third round, due out on November 15. Check your eligibility at https://help.craigslist.gov/apply/stimulus-check.pdf . Even for the most conservative of Americans, pandemic stimulus checks were a lifesaver in 2020. The French authorities have warned against Moderna's new coronavirus vaccine for under-30s after seeing a "very rare" risk of heart inflammation in people aged under 30 who have received the shot. An advisory by the country's health regulator advises against the Moderna jab for people aged under 30 because of "very rare" myocarditis risks of having a heart attack or dying. But officials have said the risk is five times less with the Pfizer jab. The EMA approved Moderna's booster vaccine for all over 18s, six months after the second dose, on Wednesday. The EMA said its review found a possible link between inflammatory heart conditions and both Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, but stressed that more research was needed to establish a clear link. Moderna's Spikevax vaccine is currently the only one available for those aged under 30, according to figures released by the UK's Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA). The HAS statement said myocarditis - or inflammation of the heart muscle - had been reported in just 11 cases since 1 March. It said of those 11 cases, nine were under 30 and had received Moderna's Spikevax vaccine. But five of them were treated with corticosteroids, which is a treatment for inflammation. One of the cases involved a 20-year-old who received a shot on 1 February and died on 13 February. A case of myocarditis was confirmed three days after he died, MHRA figures show. The rest were treated with corticosteroids, which is a treatment for inflammation. The HAS statement said myocarditis had been reported in just 11 cases since 1 March. The other nine involved people over the age of 30 and had received the Comirnaty vaccine from Pfizer and BioNTech. It has been used for those over 30 since 21 February. The EU regulator, the European medicines agency (EMA), approved Moderna's booster vaccine for all over 18s, six months after the second dose, on Wednesday. Pfizer's Comirnaty vaccine, which was approved for all over 18s in the UK last year, is the only vaccine to be licensed for over 30s.

Colonial Pipeline, the world's largest pipeline operator, has said it paid a ransom to hackers to stop its pipeline systems from crashing after a ransomware virus threatened to shut down the pipeline network . The company had previously refused to discuss the issue, and the $4.4m (£3.9m) payment is the first to be confirmed publicly by any US company . Colonial Pipeline was hit with a cyber-attack in December 2016 that caused the shutdown of its pipeline systems, which affected fuel distribution in the eastern United States . In a statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said it had had no direct contact with the ransomware threat actors and it was unclear who negotiated with the attackers . 'Critically important' The company has called the payment of the ransom "a highly controversial decision" The cyber-attack was caused by a computer program called ransomware . In November, the company paid $1.1m to hackers who were behind an earlier cyber-attack - the first ransom payment by a US company to an attacker who had threatened to shut it down . Cyber-attacks are becoming more common and are predicted to cost the US economy more than $60bn by 2025 .

The World Health Organization has designated a new variant of concern, named Omicron, to alert the international community to the potential spread of the virus among countries and communities. WHO has issued the following facts: The variant has been named B.1.1.529 and has been officially designated as a variant of concern, based on evidence that the variant has spread globally and could increase public health risks. The new variant is associated with at least two mutations that appear to affect its transmissibility and the severity of the disease it causes. There is currently no evidence that the variant increases the severity of the disease caused by the virus and we do not yet know whether it will cause more severe disease. The variant has been detected in people in multiple countries. There is concern that transmission of this variant may have increased globally. Vaccines remain essential to reducing severe disease and death caused by the virus. We have also identified three mutations in this variant that appear to increase its transmissibility. We continue to investigate the implications of these mutations as well as the other mutations in this variant, which has been detected in multiple countries. The emergence of the variant B.1.1.529 does not indicate a change in the risk posed by the variant B.1.1.7, which is associated with a higher risk of severe disease and death. Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp suffered a six-hour outage on Oct. 4 . The service outage was attributable to human error, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said . Facebook said it suffered a series of maintenance failures during the outage . Some experts and users were quick to speculate that the outage was caused by military action, as rumors spread online . (CNN) -- You might have seen online that the military raided Facebook and caused the service to briefly halt on Oct. 4. The claim is a hoax and Facebook was forced to deny it. This was the company's most serious data center outage in years, according to a statement from Mark Zuckerberg on the company's blog on Oct. 5: "We're all still shaking our heads and processing that this was the worst outage we have ever seen," he said. "We were lucky to get through another day." If Mark Zuckerberg were to die in a car crash, CNN would say, "Lucky he didn't have a job to do today," and we would be right. The real reason why Facebook was down was because we are human and we make mistakes. We know what the damage we have done to millions of users was terrible, but we want to make clear that we are here to fix it. We are working hard every day to fix it . Most of the outage happened when Facebook attempted to migrate data from servers running on older technology to newer technology. The migration took longer than expected, which is why many users may not have been able to log in to the service for six hours. When the migration was complete, Facebook restored data and services. The company said it had restored 99% of the service. The migration may have caused the outage. As for the military raid theory: It was a hoax; it originated with a Twitter user claiming that he had seen U.S. military personnel trying to take down the site, but he later retracted that claim . The military raided Facebook? That's a hoax, and it started on Twitter, according to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg. (CNN) -- A six-hour outage on Facebook and Instagram and WhatsApp appeared to be the result of military action, but it was not the case, the company said Monday. Mark Zuckerberg said on Facebook's blog that the problem was caused by "human error during routine maintenance" and promised the company would fix it. The outage occurred on Oct. 4, Mark Zuckerberg told CNN, when Facebook attempted to migrate data from servers running on older technology to newer technology. "It was a very difficult migration and it required a large amount of work to complete," Zuckerberg said at the time. "We'd like to apologize to all of those affected by this," the company said in a statement.

House Democrats: Trump is guilty of abusing his power as President of the United States . By . Amanda Schaller . In a first, the House voted to impeach President Trump for a second time on Monday, making it the most bipartisan impeachment in history. Reps. Liz Cheney (R-Wyo.) and Tom Rice (R-Ariz.) cast the decisive votes to convict the Republican president. The vote came despite the high level of polarization . Trump has only been impeached once in the past century: In 1868, he was impeached for refusing to cede control of the government to congressional Democrats . House Democrats accused Trump of abusing his powers as president to undermine the political process, including by pressuring Ukraine to investigate Joe Biden and interfering with the investigation into his associates . In a statement Monday night, Cheney called the impeachment a threat to the democratic process and said she would consider a censure vote on the president if he were to be removed from power. Rice called for Trump to be stripped of the office 'at the outset' of the new impeachment trial. Both said they would vote against Trump if they were to face the choice before the Senate . The vote is historic due to the high level of polarization and the usual party-line nature of past impeachments. It will also push the president to the right as the GOP holds an overwhelming majority in the Senate, making him harder to remove from office. Previous impeachments displayed almost no cross-party support . The impeachment votes were largely symbolic - with only 10 Republican members voting for it and 197 opposing Trump. This time, however, 11 GOP senators voted to convict the president, including Trump's top ally, Mike Pence . A look at some of the most notable moments of the impeachment vote . The impeachment vote was largely symbolic - with only 10 Republican members voting for it and 197 opposing Trump. This time, however, 11 GOP senators voted to convict the president, including Trump's top ally, Mike Pence, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky. .

A suicide attack is imminent at Kabul airport, Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond has said as he visited the Pakistan border region to meet his counterparts. James Heappey, armed forces minister, described the threat as "credible" and "imminent" and the UK government advised against the use of the airport, he said. Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond met his Pakistani counterpart Shah Mahmood Qureshi at the border on Friday evening

Heappey said: "We will continue to assess the situation on the ground and will give further instructions to those in Afghanistan as needed." A warning has been issued by the US against anyone travelling by air into the country for security reasons.

Heappey, who met his Pakistani counterpart Shah Mahmood Qureshi at the border on Friday evening, said the attack is "very, very credible" and "imminent".

"This is a very serious threat, we are in contact with the US, we are in contact with the UK, and certainly we are in contact with the Afghan government, and they are very, very keen that we get on top of this situation as soon as possible," he said.

Earlier this week, it was reported that IS militants planned to travel to Kabul from the north of Pakistan to launch a terror attack on the airport.

A number of UK officials visited the city to assess the situation, which was calm but tense in the aftermath of an attack last month on a police post in which four UK nationals were killed.

It was unclear whether a suicide bomber would be in the group travelling to Kabul and the group was due to arrive on Friday night.

The UK government urged people to stay away from the airport because of the risk of an attack. The attack is being called by the UK armed forces "credible, imminent and lethal."
