Black Lives Matter Boston is partnering with the Museum of Fine Arts Boston to show that art is a weapon against racism and inequality. Read more: Black Lives Matter: A movement that has risen from the ashes of lynchings, police brutality and slavery It is the first time an artwork has been made to support the Black Lives Matter movement in Boston - it is also part of an international campaign led by US artist Carrie Mae Weems . The MFA's prints and drawings department is featuring art by Weems and her colleagues to mark the movement's sixth anniversary and highlight its disproportionate impact on minority communities . Weems is one of the leaders of the movement, which has been inspired by the 2014 death of Trayvon Martin . 'Resist' posters are displayed across the city and will also be on display at the museum and other venues across the US in the coming weeks . The posters were first seen in London last year and since then more than 500 people have been killed by police in the US in the last six months . Black Lives Matter: Artist Carrie Mae Weems is making posters for the movement in Boston . The posters will raise awareness of racial disparity in the Covid-19 pandemic and its toll on minorities .

At least 18 Michigan students have been accused of threatening violence against public and private schools over the past week or so, three of whom have already been charged in the waterford area, the Detroit News reported Friday. The incidents have taken place over the past two weeks in and around Waterford, in the Detroit suburb of Pontiac, police said. These charges stem from threats made online and at school, including one case in which children as young as 9 allegedly wrote a threatening letter to their high school principal, according to police. Two of those accused of creating threatening letters, both 9, were detained Thursday, police said, the Detroit News reported Friday. Police in the Pontiac suburb of Oxford arrested a 10-year-old boy and a 14-year-old girl on Friday for allegedly making threats against schools. Both were in detention pending an arraignment, police in the suburb of Pontiac said. In Waterford, four students who have been accused of making serious threats against schools were taken into custody Thursday and Friday, Michigan State Police said. They were all in the eighth grade and nine years old. School officials in Oxford said they would not comment on the arrests and detention of students, but they noted that the school district is working closely with law enforcement and the courts to help those accused. The threat of violence against schools has become rampant in the nation recently, and some of the incidents have led authorities to detain students in the hope that they will rethink their actions and reconsider their threats. In metro Detroit, a total of two dozen students have been arrested and charged in recent days, according to authorities. Many of the threats against schools in Michigan appear to have been based on incidents of copycat violence against schools elsewhere in the U.S., according to officials. Authorities are warning parents that their children may face consequences if they carry out threats against schools even in jest.

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) is to require that millions of U.S. workers wear face masks at work and be tested weekly for the coronavirus, following President Biden's executive order on Tuesday. The mandate, which goes into effect Friday, is part of OSHA's efforts to protect the nation's workers from the spread of coronavirus during the first 100 days of the Biden administration. The mandate, which will require employers with at least 100 employees to provide paid time off for job-related health conditions, as well as paid time off to recover from side effects from vaccines, is part of OSHA's efforts to protect the nation's workers from the spread of coronavirus during the first 100 days of the Biden administration. President Biden's executive order, which goes into effect Wednesday, requires the U.S. to wear masks at work and be tested weekly for the coronavirus, reports Reuters. Biden said his administration will ensure that U.S. workers can access a safe, reliable vaccine once it's approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). "This is an extremely important step to getting the U.S. back on its feet, to getting our economy back on its feet, and to protecting our families," Biden said. The executive order also calls on OSHA to develop an "essential" emergency temporary standard (ETS) requiring workers to be vaccinated or tested weekly in order to protect them from the spread of the virus. "OSHA has done a great deal to help us protect our workers during this crisis," she said. "But with many Americans still working remotely, it's clear that we need to do much more." This is an open letter to President Joe Biden. President Joe Biden has said that his presidency is "about healing, not division", and has pledged to be a leader of the "greatest generation". To that end, I believe the United States deserves a president who is humble, caring, thoughtful, and worthy of this great country. That's why I'm writing to urge you not to nominate Donald Trump for the 2021 Nobel Peace Prize. This is not my first call on you, nor will be my last. I am grateful that you are listening. It is the responsibility of the next president to ensure that every American has access to the healthcare he or she needs to lead a fulfilled life, regardless of age, race, income level, gender identity, sexual preference, or disability. This will not happen if Trump remains in office. As someone who worked closely with Powell in the 1990s, when it was clear that Donald Trump did not understand the power of the presidency, I have known for some time that Trump would be a terrible president. I have also known that Powell was not the kind of person to let such things slide. The most damning of Powell's mistakes was the decision to leave the Oval Office when Colin Powell was about to be shot on the orders of Trump. If you nominate Trump for the 2021 Nobel Peace Prize, you would be sending a clear signal that he should not be allowed to run for office in the future. Joe Biden will take office on Monday, and President-elect Biden has promised a national unity government that will unite the United States to defeat the pandemic and restore the economic fortunes of the American people. In the meantime, I hope you will look to Powell as a symbol of hope for all Americans.

Kyle Rittenhouse, a white supremacist who killed two protesters during protests over the shooting of a black man in Wisconsin, has appeared on Fox News to defend his actions. Rittenhouse, 17, appeared on Tucker Carlson's Fox News show Tuesday, where he said the shooting was justified because he believed it was self-defense. Rittenhouse, a white supremacist shot dead in Kenosha, Wisconsin, said the case wasn't about his race. Rittenhouse said he supported peaceful, right-to-life protests in Kenosha . Rittenhouse, a white supremacist, was 17 when he shot two people in Kenosha, Wisconsin, in protests over the shooting of a black man . He said the case was about the right to self-defense and wasn't about his race . Rittenhouse is dead after the shootings, which left two people dead and four others injured .

The shooting of three African Americans by a white man in Kenosha, Wisconsin, in July 2020, garnered national attention during the protests against white supremacists. However, Rittenhouse's acquittal of the murder charges is a far cry from the cases of Stephen Spencer and Jaron Moore, two African Americans who were acquitted for armed self-defense. Kyle Rittenhouse was initially accused of three murders, but was later acquitted of murder charges related to the shooting rampage that left three white men dead. Rittenhouse has been accused of shooting three black men in Kenosha, Wisconsin, in July 2020. Rittenhouse was acquitted of the three murders, but was later found not guilty of manslaughter charges in connection to the shootings. On the afternoon of July 21, Rittenhouse shot three unarmed African Americans using an assault rifle, including two unarmed teenage boys. Rittenhouse was charged with all three murders, as well as manslaughter for each of the three shootings . Rittenhouse was acquitted of the manslaughter charges against him .

Salt Lake City (SLC) -- Intermountain Healthcare announced Thursday it will begin requiring all full-time caregivers and staff be vaccinated against COVID-19 starting in January. It's part of a push to protect federal health insurance for all patients. "With federal plans to change how Medicare and Medicaid payments are determined, we are implementing a health and safety policy that is required by law to protect these programs," Intermountain Healthcare said in a news release. Intermountain Healthcare is a regional health care system based in Salt Lake City. "We're going to vaccinate our caregivers and staff so the patient experience is the same as it has always been," said Mark Briesacher, chief physician executive, during a news conference Thursday morning. "We won't be stopping here." The new policy will come into effect from January 1. The federal government is in talks with states and local government about making it easier for people to get vaccinated. Approximately 80% of Intermountain's caregivers and staff are already fully vaccinated, Intermountain said in the release. The news release said the policy requires that all full-time caregivers, staff and contracted workers be vaccinated for COVID-19 by January 1. "We will have a policy where if you have any concerns, you can exempt yourself," Mark Briesacher said during the news conference. "It's the same as you would do with any other vaccination policy." He added that the federal government and the states will determine the specifics of the policy, but it's similar to the policy used by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, or CMS. "We're going to vaccinate our caregivers and staff so the patient experience is the same as it has always been," Briesacher said during the Thursday morning news conference.

Senate Democrats, led by Chuck Schumer have agreed on another stimulus package for Americans struggling with the effects of the coronavirus pandemic. Colonial Pipeline CEO: Attackers used 'single password' to break into a system protecting fuel deliveries . Senators were worried about the company's lack of a ransomware prevention plan and questioned why it paid the ransom . Asked about whether Colonial Pipeline is a cybersecurity risk to the U.S. , Sen. Blount said Colonial Pipeline was aware of its vulnerability but did not have a plan to prevent it from being abused by hackers . (CNN) A cybersecurity expert testified before U.S. senators this week about a cyberattack on the company that affected fuel deliveries to eastern Texas and Louisiana last month. Joseph Blount, CEO of Colonial Pipeline, told senators that hackers stole a single password for a legacy VPN system without multifactor authentication. He said he is unsure how the hackers' entry to the system unfolded, but added that they used a "very sophisticated and persistent hack" that took a "long time" to crack. The incident is part of a broader pattern of cyberattacks on U.S. infrastructure, the senators heard, and led to the disruption of deliveries of crude oil to eastern Texas and Louisiana. Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., said that Colonial Pipeline is "a cybersecurity risk to the U.S.," and said she is concerned about the company's lack of "adequate cybersecurity measures" to protect against such threats. Sen. Mark Warner, D-Va., asked Blount about why Colonial paid the hackers the equivalent of $700,000 in ransom, saying the payment was "risky and costly to the company" and not reflective of the company's commitment to cybersecurity. Babuk, a hacker collective known for sharing stolen data, has posted hundreds of internal documents from D.C. police department's computer network . These include daily intelligence briefing papers of police chief and reports on threats, reports the Washington Post obtained. The hacker group released the documents after negotiations failed to reach a deal with the District of Columbia Police Department . Babuk demands payment for not releasing all the data . Police have confirmed that the documents are genuine, but haven't commented on negotiations with the hackers or confirmed the data dump's authenticity . (Washington Post)

In its first public statement, Babuk declared that it had stolen more than 100 GB of data from DC police computers and that the files had been posted as a direct result of a breakdown in negotiations with the police department.

Babuk's release of stolen data was the result of what the group said was a breakdown of negotiations with District of Columbia officials, demanding money in exchange for not releasing more data. The negotiations included discussions about the posting of the files, according to the group. The documents, posted online, include files on daily intelligence briefings from the chief of the District's police department. Also found on the files are reports of threats against District police officers after the Jan. 6 attack at the U.S. Capitol .

The U.S. government plans to make it easier for pipeline operators to defend pipelines against cyber attacks after a ransomware attack on the Colonial Pipeline. The Transportation Security Administration will provide cybersecurity advice to the companies that operate the oil and gas pipelines to ensure they have the tools and resources to protect them against cyber attacks, the Department of Homeland Security announced on Tuesday . As a result of a cybersecurity audit of the Colonial Pipeline , the TSA will begin working with pipeline companies to help them develop plans to strengthen cyber controls, according to a press release from the DHS . The Colonial Pipeline was hacked in March and forced a shutdown of thousands of miles of pipeline . President Joe Biden's administration has said that the U.S. must build an infrastructure to be resilient to cyber attacks in an effort to keep fuel flowing in times of a natural disaster or attack on U.S. soil . The Colonial Pipeline was hacked in March, forcing a partial shutdown of thousands of miles of pipeline . The Colonial Pipeline was originally developed by the U.S. company Colonial Oil in the 1970s . A spokesman for Colonial Oil told Reuters the company is cooperating with federal authorities and the FBI . The pipeline was built to transport crude oil from shale deposits in the Permian Basin, a basin in north-central Texas and southwestern New Mexico . The pipeline is one of the last remaining oil pipelines that carry crude oil from the Permian Basin to refineries in Texas, according to the website for the U.S. Energy Information Agency .

When Ida hit south Louisiana on Monday night, it was more than a hurricane: it was also an assault on the city's mental health system . It was the first time a hurricane had hit Houma's medical center since it opened 70 years ago, and it was the most difficult time in its 130-year history . The storm caused the medical center's roof to collapse and flood the hospital with water . It took about a week to clear out the water, said the medical center's chief executive officer . Hurricane Ida also took an emotional toll for healthcare workers, many of who were also dealing with the coronavirus pandemic at the same time . The American Psychiatric Association reported an increase in anxiety, depression and PTSD among front-line healthcare workers . In the coming weeks, the hospital will be focusing on mental health services for the community, the medical center's head says . A massive hurricane in Louisiana ripped the roof off a Houma hospital . By . John Sutter . and John Harnish . Associated Press . A massive hurricane hit Louisiana's south . A massive storm tore a roof off a Houma hospital on Monday night, flooding the hospital's surgical floor and leaving patients lying in pools of water . The storm hit south Louisiana as a COVID-19 surge forced the evacuation of thousands of people, including many patients from the Houma Leonard J. Chabert Medical Center. The storm took a massive toll on the city, particularly on health workers. The Houma hospital has been operating since 1870, but it was not ready for this type of storm . The hospital, which is undergoing a major renovation and expansion, was already overwhelmed by the number of COVID-19 patients it received as the devastating virus swept through Houma and other parts of the state. At the time of the storm, the medical center was already running on its last reserves of water because of the thousands of patients it was processing at the same time as its overflowing COVID-19 patients. "It was more than just a hurricane," said hospital's CEO, Jay Smith. "It felt like a very long, heavy weight was on my shoulders." The hospital was not prepared for the kind of storm it encountered on Monday night. In the initial stages of the storm, water started to pour down from the hospital's roof, the CEO said. By the time the flood was under control, it had soaked the medical center's surgical floor and left patients lying in puddles of water. As the storm progressed, Smith said the hospital's patients were evacuated and discharged to other hospitals in the region, as they could not be risked being evacuated back to their flooded rooms. As a result, the number of patients the medical center was processing at the same time was significantly reduced, the CEO said.

The last known photographs of missing Utah high school student Gabby Petito were taken at Bryce Canyon National Park in June 2018. Her body has not been found, despite extensive searches by police and the US Forest Service. FOX 13 News Utah set up a timeline of her travels in Utah, largely based on Instagram posts by her boyfriend, Brian Laundrie, who was arrested in Utah last month on charges of first-degree murder. Gabby used an app called AllTrails to document her hiking and driving activities, which often matched her Instagram posts. The last hike she documented on AllTrails was in Mystic Hot Springs on July 24. The timeline covers the past three months since Gabby disappeared in May 2018, when she went hiking alone with her boyfriend at Zion National Park in Utah. A FOX 13 News Utah photographer was able to access the Instagram account of Brian Laundrie, her boyfriend, during the time she was missing, and was able to compile this timeline. In June 2018, she documented her last hike at Mystic Hot Springs, at which point she left the park and headed for Utah's South Rim of the Grand Canyon, where she stayed for a few days. She went to Bryce Canyon, Zion, and Canyonlands in the summer of last year, mostly on her own but also with her boyfriend, who often accompanied her on her trips. In August 2018, Brian Laundrie traveled to the Grand Canyon in a separate car with her, and she documented all of the park's trails in AllTrails, a website with trail maps. The last known photographs of Gabby Petito were taken at Bryce Canyon National Park in June 2018. Her body has not been found. This FOX 13 News Utah photographer was able to access Brian Laundrie's Instagram account during the time she was missing, and was able to compile this timeline.

Donald Trump is no longer president of the United States of America. In less than 12 months, he and his administration have had more than their share of controversies, but the most significant have been the impeachment proceedings against him, which led to his removal from office, and the coronavirus pandemic, which led to the first economic shutdown of U.S. history. With that said, there have been plenty of other things to talk about during his final months in office, so here are the five biggest stories that have dominated the news during his presidency. 1. Impeachment proceedings led to Trump's removal from office After the first debate, Trump's campaign repeatedly claimed the results had been rigged and he would win the election by a landslide if it were decided based on votes from the popular vote, rather than the electoral college. In October 2016, Donald Trump was elected president in the first U.S. presidential election in a generation to be decided by vote from the electoral college, which is based on votes from each state. In January 2017, the Republican took office after winning 270 electoral college votes over his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton. During his final months in office, Trump was removed from office twice for breaching U.S. impeachment proceedings. He was charged with obstructing Congress, which led to him being impeached for the second time in December 2019, and a third time in February 2020. Both times he was found guilty of the offence, and the House of Representatives voted to send his case to the Senate, where he faces a second trial. 2. Coronavirus outbreak led to the first economic shutdown of U.S. history On March 27, 2020, President Trump declared the U.S. was at a public health emergency due to coronavirus and called on people to stay at home. The order came three days after the first person in the U.S. tested positive for the virus. By March 30, more than 25,000 people in the U.S. had tested positive for the virus, according to data from Johns Hopkins University. By May, nearly 1 million people in the U.S. had tested positive for the virus and the U.S. had become the worst-hit country by number of cases. In April, the first death due to coronavirus was reported in the U.S. The number of cases in the U.S. increased by more than 600% by the end of April and more than 300% by the end of May. 3. Trump's successor Joe Biden was inaugurated on January 20 On January 20, Joe Biden was inaugurated as the 46th U.S. president. The inauguration was the first to be held without Trump in the White House for nearly 20 years.

Bombing operations: US-led coalition bombs Taliban and al-Qaeda facilities in Afghanistan, targeting Kabul, Kandahar, and Jalalabad. The Taliban, in control after Soviet occupation and civil war, do not surrender Bin Laden. Their defense capabilities are destroyed. A new Afghan constitution is established after negotiations, leading to presidential elections in October 2004. NATO ends its combat operations in Afghanistan, transitioning the US focus to training and supporting Afghan security forces. Afghan President Ashraf Ghani reports over 45,000 members of the country's security forces have died since 2014, a higher figure than previously known. Use #BBCSafety to let us know what you think about this topic. The Afghan national army and police are struggling to control security in the country, and US-led coalition air strikes against suspected al-Qaeda militants and the Taliban militia have contributed to the rise in violence. As a result, more than 45,000 members of the security forces have died in the past five years, the UN says in its most recent report. The Taliban are a group that has been in power since 2001. They've been on the rise during the last decade, and are in control of the Afghan capital, Kabul, the country's second most populated city, Kandahar, and the northern city of Jalalabad, the BBC News website reports.

Colin Powell, former Secretary of State and U.S. Army General, has died at the age of 83 after a long battle with cancer. His death will be felt by all Americans and his legacy will be remembered for decades to come. Powell was a former Secretary of State and U.S. Army General who served his country faithfully, with courage and bravery. Colin Powell was born in 1937, and was well known for breaking down barriers with his military and diplomatic accomplishments as a U.S. General and Secretary of State. He is also remembered for being a role model for young Americans of all backgrounds. Powell was an inspiring force behind the Army Cadet Command, which is based at Fort Knox. Today, the United States Army Cadet Command continues to grow in influence and recognition around the world. He was known as a mentor for the U.S. Army's cadet corps, as well as for Cadets of other armed forces across the world. In particular, he inspired the cadets of Fort Leavenworth to pursue careers in the U.S. Army, as well as the U.S. Navy and U.S. Air Force. Powell was one of the most recognized people in the world, and he will be greatly missed by all who know him. The U.S. Army Cadet Command is a part of Fort Knox and is responsible for education, leadership, and leadership development for the Cadet Corps. The cadet corps continues to grow in influence and recognition around the world, and the influence of the Army Cadet Command is evident across the country and around the world. While Colin Powell's accomplishments were remarkable, his greatest legacy will be his influence on cadets of the Army, Navy, and Air Force around the world, and what he taught them to do. Powell served as an Army General for over 20 years, and was the first U.S. general to be awarded the Distinguished Service Cross and the Distinguished Service medal. He also served as the U.S. Secretary of State for 9 years, making him one of the longest serving Secretaries of State in U.S.

Extreme weather across Texas has caused massive power outages that are expected to last for days, leaving millions without electricity. This is the third winter storm that has hit Texas in the space of a month, and has been named the most extreme to hit the state in more than a decade. It will also push the average temperature below freezing for the first time in nearly six decades, though not to as low as the winter of 1969-70. The rolling blackouts were announced Tuesday morning by the Southwest Power Pool, which oversees the distribution of electricity across Texas, Oklahoma, and some parts of Mexico. The Southwest Power Pool said Texas had no choice but to shut its main transmission lines, which account for more than two-thirds of the state's electricity production, in response to the severe winter storm. "The power grid is down and we cannot restore power quickly enough to meet demand," Power Pool executive vice president and president of Texas, Paul Menchaca, told reporters. "We're working as hard as we can, but we can't restore power on demand at this point." More than two million people were left in the dark across Texas, according to the power company Entergy. While the rolling blackouts caused some economic disruption for businesses, most of the impact came down to inconvenience for customers. "It's going to take days, probably a week, for us not to be able to turn on our heaters. It's going to be cold, and it's going to be hard, but we've got to go through it," Travis County, Texas, fire chief Mike Smith said. The severe weather system that has hit Texas and parts of Oklahoma resulted in more than 3,000 power outages, with 2 million people in Texas without power Tuesday . The Texas Energy Office said the cold spell is the second-deepest recorded in the state . The severe weather system will lead to the lowest temperatures in Texas in more than half a century . Some 1 million people were affected by the severe weather system in the Southwest Power Pool system, which includes Texas, Oklahoma and parts of Mexico . More than 3,000 power outages were reported in Texas and over 3 million people were without power in Oklahoma . The severe weather system has led to the lowest temperatures ever recorded in Texas .

Powell, the first Black chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, writes about how Donald Trump has tried to destroy the country that he served as president for eight years. A former presidential candidate, Powell is the first Black chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, a position he filled when President Ronald Reagan was in office. Powell said his decision to join Trump's presidential campaign was an attempt to oppose the Republican Party, which he said had become too extreme. Powell wrote a series of letters to the Washington Post in 2015 in which he expressed his concerns about the direction the Republican Party was taking under Donald Trump's leadership, and about the way the Trump administration had damaged U.S. democracy. Donald Trump's response: Donald Trump hit back at Colin L. Powell's column, denigrating his career, praising himself and referring to his opponent as a criminal. In the column, Powell said that Trump's response to the violence that broke out in the U.S. during the 2016 campaign was more important than whether he won the election. A former presidential candidate, Colin L. Powell served as the first Black chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff when President Ronald Reagan was in office. Powell praised President Barack Obama and praised his administration, but criticized Trump for its response to the storming of the U.S. Capitol in the fall of last year.

President Joe Biden issued a third stimulus payment to U.S. taxpayers on Wednesday . The payments are based on the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021, signed into law by President Joe Biden on March 11. Individuals and families may receive up to $1,400 per qualifying member, including adult and child dependents. Income limits for full payments start phasing out at $75,000 for single filers, $150,000 for married filing jointly, and $112,500 for heads of household. Check out how to verify if you're eligible and how to receive your payment on the IRS website. President Joe Biden signed a new stimulus bill on Wednesday . The American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 will provide $1400 per person . The maximum amount of money you can receive is $75,000 per adult or $25,000 per child . Individuals who earn $200,000 or more will receive the second payment .

Americans are hungry for a second stimulus check to help them weather the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic. But with the economy improving and unemployment claims down sharply, it looks increasingly unlikely that Congress or President Trump will give Americans a fourth stimulus check at this time. The White House released its weekly unemployment claims report on Tuesday and indicated the number of Americans claiming unemployment insurance fell by 2.2 million in August, the highest drop since April. While that is a much bigger drop than the 12.7 million who applied for unemployment in August, it is still only 12% of the total number of Americans unemployed during the same month. While the economy appears to be getting back in gear, many are still craving a second stimulus check from the White House or Congress to help pay their bills. That's why over 2.8 million Americans have signed a petition for a $2,000 monthly stimulus payment that would be paid out for three months in a row. "We need this now," Change.org petition creator Stephanie Bonin told USA Today. "We are at a critical time, and it's so important to make sure the stimulus checks get in to the hands of those most in need." Bonin pointed out the importance of getting the stimulus check to the people who need it most. In the United States, 2 million more people applied for unemployment insurance in August than in July. Bonin said the reason for the jump is because many Americans had to stop working to care for elderly family members or sick family members during the pandemic.

CNN's Chris Cuomo has been embroiled in controversy since the start of the campaign leading up to New York's gubernatorial election last year and has grown ever more prominent on the television news show during the course of the primary season and the main election. Cuomo, a longtime friend and ally of governor Andrew Cuomo (D-NY), was a key adviser for his brother on his campaign. Now, Cuomo and his CNN team are facing a barrage of criticism from fellow New York journalism experts over their role in the scandal involving Governor Andrew Cuomo's brother's role in the governor's office. Cuomo says he will remain with the CNN program despite calls from other New York to fire him. Cuomo and his office have said they were not present at the time any wrongdoing was being discussed. He said his brother's decision to step down as the head of New York's emergency services had nothing to do with the news show. Cuomo is also under fire from media watchdogs and others for the way in which he has portrayed the governor's brother, Andrew Cuomo. Northeastern University experts say that Chris Cuomo and CNN's management team are responsible for the blurred lines that have been drawn between Cuomo's personal and professional life. Cuomo has said his news show is about New York, but many observers think the show is more about Cuomo himself.

This year, the government has spent more than $1 billion to defend against ransomware attacks on federal networks. Cybercriminals are increasingly targeting companies around the world to steal data, collect a ransom, and spread the malware to other systems.

Cybersecurity experts say that companies around the world have been targeted with ransomware in recent years, and last month a major attack highlighted the potential threat ransomware poses to national security and to the economy.

On March 30, hackers encrypted data at Colonial Pipeline and demanded a ransom of $850,000, or $1.2 million in bitcoin. Security experts say that the $1.2 million was the maximum the company could afford. Even that amount was considered too much for most companies. But the company did comply and paid.

Now, a study conducted by the Ponemon Institute for Cybersecurity suggests that ransomware could cost businesses $16 billion in 2016. This is a jump from the estimated $11.3 billion spent in 2015. The study also found that the amount of ransom paid out by businesses has risen exponentially over the past few years.

The Ponemon study, which looked at more than 1,700 companies, found that 50 percent of the victims of ransomware attacks in 2016 paid a ransom. The average amount a company paid in ransom last year was estimated at about $312,000. But the report found that the actual average amount paid out was $640,000, and that the average number of days to recover data was about 4.5 days.

Cybersecurity expert Dr. David Krebs, author of the Ponemon study and professor at the University of Minnesota, said it was not surprising the average amount paid was higher than the amount paid last year. The reasons for the higher amount were not clear, he said. "It's always interesting to know what makes people decide to pay," Krebs said.

The Ponemon Institute for Cybersecurity also looked at ransomware attacks on government networks. That category included schools, government agencies, hospitals, and other health care facilities, as well as banks and financial institutions. Of that group, Ponemon found that the average amount paid out in ransom was about $262,000. But the average number of days to recover data was just 2.4 days. The study also found that the amount of ransomware paid out by government networks was the lowest of the three groups.

Ponemon found that the most common method of payment was bitcoin, which was used in about a third of ransomware attacks it studied. About a third of attacks also required payment in cash, and about a quarter used credit cards.

On Monday, the US Senate passed the largest stimulus package in US history - over $900 billion. But what impact will the bill have on the finances of US families? The US Senate passed its third stimulus bill, which contains a $1,400 per adult and $600 per child check. But will this have any effect on household financial stability? This is an analysis of how the new stimulus package will impact households. By John CampbellBusiness and finance editor, Morning Consult As a journalist writing about the economy, I find the focus of political debate and economic commentary on the third stimulus bill to be a bit of a surprise. While the overall size and timing of the bill is good, the lack of data on the impact on households' ability to pay their bills has been striking, as have some of the policy suggestions contained in the bill. When the US Senate passed its first $2 trillion bill in 2009, the debate raged for months over the impact on household finances and consumer spending, including the role of student loans and the potential impact of the massive tax cut. Of course we all liked it when the student loans were forgiven, but that is not the point. What is interesting to note is that when we looked at the financial situation of US families, we saw that it was not the most popular bill, despite the amount it was spent. This is because at that time, there was limited data on the financial situation of US families. This time around, there has been even more focus on the impact of the stimulus package on consumer spending. That is a bit of a surprise, in my view, given that traditional economic data like the GDP and consumer spending data do not provide a full picture of the distribution of savings among the US population. So let's look at the data from one of the most comprehensive sources we have - Morning Consult. It tracks all aspects of the US household finances and its tracking data includes all three stimulus packages in addition to all of the other economic policies in the past 20 years. So let's look at the distribution of savings among the US households. We looked at two different scenarios: first, let's assume we are on a recovery, with the economy growing and consumer spending rising, and second, let's look at an economic downturn. So let's assume that we are on a recovery, with the economy growing and... 1. This time around, there has been even more focus on the impact of the stimulus package on consumer spending. This is a bit of a surprise, in my view, given that traditional economic data like the GDP and consumer spending data do not provide a full picture of the distribution of savings among the US population. So let's look at the data from one of the most comprehensive sources we have - Morning Consult. 2. The analysis highlights the lack of data-driven debate on the impact of the third stimulus package on households' ability to pay bills. 3. Focus of debate has predominantly been on the impact of stimulus packages on consumer spending. 4. Traditional economic data like GDP and consumer spending data do not provide insight into the distribution of savings. 5.

CNN has terminated Chris Cuomo from his position as chief political correspondent following a review by a law firm of his role in his brother's defense against sexual harassment allegations. Cuomo had been suspended indefinitely two days ago amid the allegations, and his suspension was later changed to termination. Cuomo had been suspended indefinitely earlier in the week . Cuomo will be replaced temporarily by CNN anchor Michael Smerconish. Cuomo was fired from NBC News in 2011 following an internal investigation into sexual harassment allegations against him . Cuomo was suspended from CNN in April 2016 following an internal investigation into sexual harassment allegations against him . Cuomo has covered the political side of politics for CNN since 2003 . The Super Bowl victory for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers wasn't just about one man - it was a team effort. This is the key takeaway of the Super Bowl article by BBC Sports Correspondent Matt Lawton. Click here to read the full article The NFL's biggest game - and arguably the greatest sports spectacle - saw the Buccaneers take on the Kansas City Chiefs on Sunday night in Tampa Bay's Raymond James Stadium. Despite the loss by the Buccaneers, their win was significant because it was their first Super Bowl championship in franchise history - and the first time that three-time Super Bowl-winning quarterback Tom Brady has won the title in the league's 30-year-old history. The Buccaneers defeated a Chiefs team who were favourites to lift the trophy for the third time in five years (the previous one came in 2012). It was also Tom Brady's fifth Super Bowl title in the league's 30-year history, although only the first in the era of NFL 2.0. Tampa Bay Buccaneers 31-9 Kansas City Chiefs

A shooting death in Kenosha, Wisconsin, earlier this month has divided the U.S. into two competing camps. A heavily armed white man was arrested for killing two black men and wounding a third man.

The verdict has elicited polarized reactions, with right-wing groups and the National Rifle Association celebrating, and liberal leaders expressing concerns over vigilantism.

However, what the case reveals is a deep rift in U.S. society that will not be easily fixed. It has touched on divisive issues like gun rights, police brutality, and racial injustice. It has also highlighted the deep divides between liberal and conservative views on how to respond to violence.

The case has also sparked an interesting debate about the meaning of self-defense. Rittenhouse, 18, claimed self-defense after fatally shooting two men and wounding a third during protests in Kenosha on Aug. 21. The men were in a crowd of people demonstrating against the police and protesting the fatal shooting of Jacob Blake, a black man, by a white police officer. Supporters of the shooting said it was justified, but many liberal leaders were critical of Rittenhouse.

Supporters of Kyle Rittenhouse, right, who killed two black protesters and wounded a policeman in Kenosha, Wisconsin, claim that he was justified in his actions.

Rittenhouse was convicted last week of manslaughter in the deaths and is now accused of a hate crime in the police shooting of Jacob Blake. President Donald Trump's son-in-law and top advisor, Jared Kushner, has repeatedly called Rittenhouse a hero.

Supporters of Kyle Rittenhouse, right, who killed two black protesters and wounded a policeman in Kenosha, Wisconsin, say that he was justified in his actions. Rittenhouse was convicted last week of manslaughter in the deaths of the two men and is now accused of a hate crime in the police shooting of Jacob Blake. President Donald Trump's son-in-law and top advisor, Jared Kushner, has repeatedly called Rittenhouse a hero.

The shooting has not only been a tragic event for the family of the three men killed. It also highlights the deep divides between the black community and the white community in Kenosha and beyond. A young white man who killed three black protesters has divided the country. This is a deeply disturbing and disturbing event.

A year after the first cases of Covid-19 were confirmed in the US, health officials and experts are still struggling to figure out the full extent of the impacts of the Delta variant and its potential impact on unvaccinated individuals. President Trump's supporters were angry about the outcome of the 2020 election, so he decided to hold a rally before the inauguration. On January 6, they gathered in Washington, DC and marched towards the Capitol. The riot that followed left four people dead and hundreds injured. But it wasn't just the violence that left an indelible mark on the city. Trump supporters marched on the capital for days afterwards, threatening the peaceful transition of power to Joe Biden. Trump supporters looted offices inside the Capitol after the riot on January 6 . In his article, Slate's Andrew Bacevich details how the mood darkened as the protesters approached the Capitol . His piece is based on interviews, reports and eyewitness accounts . By . Andrew Bacevich . PUBLISHED: . 07:21 EST, 3 January 2021 . | . UPDATED: . 07:21 EST, 3 January 2021 . As the four people who died at the heart of Donald Trump's January 6 storming of the US Capitol died, a handful of survivors spoke about what they saw. The president had encouraged his supporters to march toward the capital, and they were giddy in their victory. As they marched toward the US Capitol, the mood darkened. There was a sense of giddy triumph, but also of desperation. President Trump's . supporters, after the riot on January 6, breached the Capitol and looted offices . 'The atmosphere here was that of a war zone', said a survivor, who asked to remain anonymous. 'The protesters were wildly excited, but they were also furious.' On the night of the Capitol attack, Donald Trump called a rally at the Ellipse in the Washington district, near the White House. The marchers, who were carrying Trump flags and other banners, arrived at the White House at dawn. They were cheered on by thousands of Trump supporters who had gathered in the street. 'The protesters chanted that Trump would never be defeated, and there were chants of 'Four more years',' one survivor told me. 'At the same time, they were chanting 'death to democrats.' That was a sign that the mood darkened after the marchers . entered the Capitol. Trump supporters at the Capitol after the riot on January 6 . The Capitol's galleries are now adorned with the . remains of what once stood inside the building. On the . Capitol steps, the remains of . the marble steps that . once stood inside the building are now . adorned with the . remains of what once stood inside the building . The . remains of... The author interviewed survivors, reporters and eyewitnesses who were at the scene of the riot on January 6 .

Colin Powell died on Friday, just two days after being diagnosed with COVID-19 complications amid a cancer battle, officials confirmed to CBS News. The former secretary of state and National Security Advisor served four presidents and led the U.S. in the invasion of Iraq, among other leadership roles, as well as 9/11. President Biden ordered flags at half-staff until October 22 in Powell's memory. Former National Security Advisor and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Colin Powell died of COVID-19 complications on Friday at age 84. Powell was diagnosed with COVID-19 complications two weeks after being vaccinated against the virus . Powell was treated for multiple myeloma, a blood cancer affecting the immune system . President Biden ordered flags at half-staff until October 22 in Powell's memory . Powell was the first Black secretary of state and served under four presidents, including as National Security Advisor and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff . Powell led the State Department during the 9/11 attacks and supported the invasion of Iraq, later calling his UN speech on WMDs a "blot" on his record . The former National Security Advisor and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff was diagnosed with COVID-19 two weeks after being vaccinated . "We continue to take all necessary measures to expedite the development and authorization of COVID-19 tests," he said. The FDA has recently taken various measures throughout the pandemic to facilitate the development and authorization of COVID-19 tests, including establishing an expedited review process for rapid development and approval of COVID-19 testing devices.

Vice President Kamala Harris will lead the National Space Council under a new executive order . It will continue operations under the Trump administration after Biden took power . Harris will focus on STEM education, cybersecurity, commercial space activity, diversity, and peaceful space norms . The council was previously led by Vice President Mike Pence during the Trump administration, who had revived the council in 2017 . The council's mission under the new order is to continue the Trump administration's actions to advance the national security interests in space, including those related to commerce, education, research and development, and national security and international diplomacy . By . Jillian Harris and Megan Davis . PUBLISHED: . 06:48 EST, 8 January 2021 . | . UPDATED: . 06:51 EST, 8 January 2021 . The Biden administration has confirmed the details of its much-anticipated space policy, which has been a focus of much of the president-elect's presidency. Kamala Harris will now chair the National Space Council, a group tasked with 'continuing the operation' of the Trump administration's actions related to space . Kamala Harris announced her new role in a tweet on Wednesday evening, writing: 'With my leadership of the National Space Council, I will focus on STEM education, cybersecurity, commercial space activity, diversity, and peaceful space norms.' The National Space Council previously led by vice president Mike Pence during the Trump administration, which revived the council in 2017. It aims to focus on STEM education, cybersecurity, commercial space activity, diversity, and peaceful space norms . The council's actions under the order will be reviewed .

In the next few weeks, millions of Americans will receive payments of up to $1,400 in federal stimulus checks for themselves and their families. President Biden is expected to sign a new stimulus bill that will include a new and much larger version of the American Rescue Plan, which was signed by President Trump in March 2020. How the American Rescue Plan works The American Rescue Plan expanded the federal Child Tax Credit, providing direct payments to families. Before the pandemic, the federal Child Tax Credit paid out to families on a sliding scale based on income level, with a maximum amount of $12,100 in a given year. Now, the American Rescue Plan will provide an additional $300 per child under 6, $250 per child ages 6 to 17, and $500 per child ages 18 to 29. The American Rescue Plan, which included a new round of stimulus payments, also expanded the child care benefit for families with children. The Child Care Benefit will increase the amount that families can save from taxes by $1,000 per child under 6 and $400 per child ages 6 to 17. President Biden's Stimulus Bill to Expand Child Tax Credits, Payments to Families The American Rescue Plan was signed by President Trump in March 2020

Colin Powell, one of the most decorated U.S. military leaders of all time, died of complications stemming from COVID-19 and an underlying condition, his family said Monday. He was 84. Powell was one of the most decorated military leaders in U.S. history. A U.N. secretary-general once described Powell as the greatest statesman he'd ever met. He served as secretary of state, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and as national security adviser under President George W. Bush. The first black secretary of state, Powell fought for the United States in the Vietnam War and in the Persian Gulf. He resigned from the post in 2005, blaming Iraq for the 2003 invasion. Powell had served as secretary of state, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and as national security adviser under President George W. Bush. He resigned in 2005, blaming Iraq for the 2003 invasion. Powell was among the most decorated military leaders in U.S. history. He served under presidents George H.W. Bush, Bill Clinton, and George W. The photo that some people are claiming shows the current route of the Ever Given cargo ship was originally supposed to take has come under scrutiny for a couple of reasons. It's just one in a long list of fake pictures circulated on the internet following a major disruption to the Suez Canal on March 23. This morning we learned that after the Ever Given had been released from its position on the canal, it began its usual route. So it's important to remember that while this photo is a plausible depiction of the Ever Given cargo ship's route before it was caught in the Suez Canal, the ship's route hasn't always been as it is now. So what was the actual route of the Ever Given? Was the ship intended to be drawn in the way that the photo appears to be? Was the route intended to resemble a crude drawing of a penis? First things first: a picture is worth a thousand words, but this one isn't worth too much. The image is genuine and shows the same route as the ship has always taken before it was stuck in the Suez Canal. That means the following things.

The image depicts the full route of the Ever Given cargo ship from the start of its usual route, through the Suez Canal, out to the shipyard that it was built at in the Port of Mombasa. It was drawn in exactly the same way as the route is now, with the lines drawn in the same scale as the lines on the physical map. It does not resemble a drawing of a penis. And, importantly, it is not a drawing of the route that was taken by the Ever Given when it got caught in the Suez Canal.

It's worth pointing out that the photo was posted to Twitter by the ship's owner, but not by the company that ran the Suez Canal, nor by the company that owns the ship. While the photo is true, there's nothing to suggest it was meant to look like a crude drawing of a penis. It was not the intention to draw the route of the ship in this way. What's next

President Joe Biden issues national security memo on cybersecurity The White House says the goal is to help protect critical infrastructure from cyberattacks Industrial control systems (ICS) and operational technologies (OT) must meet new standards for cybersecurity, new report says The Trump administration's decision to cut funding to many of these groups raised serious concerns about overall security. The Biden administration is making efforts to address them, the new memo from National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan says.

The memo, released Monday, aims to address the shortcomings of the patchwork of sector-specific cybersecurity laws that apply to different kinds of infrastructure, such as power, water and transportation networks, as well as government networks, the report said. The administration's focus has been on ICS and OT networks in the industrial sector, which is the most likely to be impacted by a cyberattack, it said.

"This memo is a response to the increased threat and potential consequences of cyberattacks on critical infrastructure," the White House said in a statement.

It said the new national security memo, signed by Joe Biden's national security advisor, will "urgently address industry weaknesses in the security of critical infrastructure." "These weaknesses will not be allowed to continue," the statement said.

The memo is designed to "encourage voluntary adoption of improved cybersecurity standards by infrastructure owners and operators, and will focus on industrial control systems (ICS) and operational technologies (OT) in order to protect their integrity", it said.

Industrial control systems and operational technologies are crucial for the functionality of infrastructure, the report adds.

The Biden-Harris Administration will work to ensure federal funding for expanded Medicaid postnatal coverage, address the disparity in Native American women's access to care, and improve maternal health care in general during a White House Maternal Health Day of Action on October 16, 2021. Vice President Kamala Harris will lead a Call to Action to improve maternal health and reduce mortality and morbidity on October 16, 2021, and will announce new commitments under the Build Back Better Act. In addition, the Executive Office of the President will coordinate a series of activities across the federal government to increase awareness of maternal health issues and improve access to maternal health care, especially for Native American and Black women. The White House Maternal Health Day of Action will focus on the following five topics: Medicaid postpartum coverage; Native American women's health; addressing maternal health disparities among Native American and Black women; improving access to and quality of maternity care for all women; and the use of electronic health records.

On Twitter: Donald Trump's account has been permanently suspended following his attacks on democracy The President's account had been censored before this latest ban by Twitter . Trump used Twitter extensively throughout his tenure as US president . He launched attacks on critics of his presidency and his followers attacked him for his behaviour on social media . Peter Costanzo was one of Donald Trump's first advisers on Twitter . He helped Trump get his Twitter handle and advised him on his style on the platform . Donald Trump's Twitter account has been permanently suspended after the social media giant banned his account for incitement of violence and abusive posts. Trump used the platform extensively during his presidency to communicate directly with the public, bypass official media channels. Trump launched attacks on critics of his presidency, including his former rival Hillary Clinton, and his followers attacked him for his behaviour. Asked why he had taken the action, a Twitter spokesperson said: 'We are removing the account due to concerns of further incitement of violence.' He added: 'We are not removing Donald Trump's account, but rather suspending it for a period of time.' Trump had been accused of inciting violence in response to a mob of his supporters attacking the US Capitol on 6 January, in which five people were killed. Trump's account had previously been censored several times by Twitter. He had initially tried to get the account banned, but Twitter said that it could not because there were no violent posts made from it. However, the social media giant later said that Trump's account could be permanently banned if there were further attacks on other users and if the President's messages were deemed abusive. Peter Costanzo, one of Donald Trump's advisers, has now been suspended from Twitter . He is one of the first people to have had their Twitter handle banned .

Griddy Energy has reached a settlement with Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton over the winter storm of 2016 that left millions of Texans without power. In a settlement announced by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton on Tuesday night, Griddy Energy is to pay $2.5 million in damages to customers that received very high electricity bills during the storm. The bill was caused when the company offered consumers a 'wholesale electricity rate' to pay for high-priced power generated by the company's own nuclear plants. The agency sued the company after thousands of customers complained about bills ranging from $2,000 to $13,000. "This settlement marks an important step forward in the fight to hold energy suppliers accountable," Attorney General Paxton said. The new settlement will prevent Griddy Energy from billing any of its Texas customers for any future power bills from the storm. In a statement to CNN, Griddy Energy said it "remains committed to providing Texas with reliable, affordable energy for years to come". Griddy Energy will pay $2.5 million to settle the storm bill . The company will also stop billing its Texas customers for future power from the winter storm .

Supporters of renaming the Super Bowl MVP Trophy for Tom Brady said the late NFL commissioner Pete Rozelle is deserving of such recognition for his work. Opponents of renaming the award said Rozelle's accomplishment must be recognized, but that Tom Brady should take the award, or it should be named after someone else who played an integral role in the Super Bowl. "We are all in agreement that Pete Rozelle deserved this honor," David Smith said.

Waco High School parents say they are concerned that their children have received nonstop threats about a possible shooting at the school over the past few days, and have even been seen posting threats on social media. WACO — Texas parents say they are worried about school shootings nationwide, yet their children often receive threats on social media about a possible shooting at Waco High School. In an email to the Sun yesterday, parents said they received threats to their children nonstop on Snapchat and Twitter, which are popular platforms, especially among high school kids. "There have been a lot of threats that have occurred at my son's school and we feel like we're being put at risk," said one mother. "We think Waco High School should follow through with making sure our kids are safe from potential hazards." A Waco High School spokeswoman said the school is aware of the situation and will be taking steps to prevent any more threats from happening at the school. "We're aware of this as well," she said. The Biden administration on Tuesday unveiled an increase in cybersecurity funding for the Department of Energy, the latest step in a multi-pronged effort to bolster cybersecurity as the federal government works with private organizations to build a more resilient national infrastructure. Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm announced the Department of Energy requests a $201 million increase in its cybersecurity budget for fiscal 2022. That's up from $157 million in fiscal 2021, according to a Department of Energy statement. The funding is part of a broader push by the Biden administration to improve cyber-security across federal agencies to prevent government data from being accessed by hackers. The increase is to help bolster cybersecurity efforts, addressing supply chain and tech infrastructure gaps, according to a Department of Energy statement. "We cannot afford for government agencies to fall victim to the same cybersecurity threats that businesses face on a daily basis," Granholm said in a statement. "Our cybersecurity programs are already among the strongest in the federal government. But, we also need to improve how we deliver cybersecurity training and education to government employees, improve our cybersecurity incident response practices, and bolster our ability to respond to large-scale cyber-attacks and incidents, such as those experienced by the Colonial Pipeline." Since joining the Biden administration on January 20, Granholm has championed a multi-pronged effort to address cybersecurity gaps across government agencies, including increasing cybersecurity funding, a more robust cyber-defense and an initiative to raise cybersecurity awareness among employees and contractors.

Fairfield Inn and Suites where Utah girl is missing was under investigation by the FBI, police, staff say . FBI and police confirm Gabby Petito stayed there for more than a day . Petito's stepfather criticizes FBI for not helping find daughter . She left home with her estranged boyfriend who has been charged with her kidnapping . (CNN) -- The search for the missing Utah teenager has shifted focus to Wyoming, after authorities confirmed that Gabby Petito stayed in a Fairfield Inn and Suites in Cheyenne for more than a day, CNN affiliate FOX 13 News reports. The hotel staff said that agents from the FBI and Salt Lake County police visited the hotel recently and confirmed Petito stayed at the hotel on August 24, according to the affiliate. The FBI and police did not respond to CNN's request for comment. Gabby was last seen on August 24 near Salt Lake City International Airport. The FBI confirmed that the phone records from her phone were being analyzed and that the social media accounts of the boyfriend were being probed as part of the search. Gabby has been missing since she left home with estranged boyfriend Brian Laundrie on Aug. 21. She has been on the run from her parents since July 30. She last was seen in a motel near Salt Lake International Airport. The stepfather of Gabby, James Schmidt, said Monday that the FBI has not been cooperative in finding his daughter. "Since the day she disappeared, he's (Brian Laundrie) never said a word to police officers, to my wife," Schmidt said. "He has nothing to do with his own daughter's disappearance. "I don't really know why he doesn't cooperate, but I know he's not a murderer. If he is a murderer, why would he stay quiet?" He also said that he believes that Laundrie is hiding in Wyoming, according to FOX 13 News. "Laundrie, if he is hiding, he certainly doesn't know where to hide from me." Gabby left home with her estranged boyfriend who has been charged with her kidnapping . Brian Laundrie was arrested in Michigan on August 23. He has been charged with felony kidnapping and felony child endangerment, according to the U.S. Attorney's Office. He is due in court on September 6 . Brian Laundrie, 26, was charged in the kidnapping of his ex-girlfriend . He is due in court on September 6 . Gabby left home with her estranged boyfriend . Laundrie has been arrested in Michigan . His estranged girlfriend was last seen at a motel near Salt Lake International Airport on August 24 .

People in the UK are being offered coronavirus vaccines, but it's important to know how effective they are in protecting people against the disease. Here are some of the key facts you should know about the vaccines being offered in the UK and how effective they are.

What are the two vaccines being offered in the UK?

The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine requires two doses

The Johnson & Johnson vaccine requires one dose

How does the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine work?

The vaccine uses mRNA technology to trigger an immune response against the coronavirus.

How does the Moderna vaccine work?

The vaccine uses mRNA technology to trigger an immune response against the coronavirus.

What is required for the vaccines to work?

The vaccines must be delivered into a person's immune system, which then triggers an immune response against the virus.

How long do the vaccines take to work?

The vaccines work best when they are given as two doses, usually 12 weeks apart.

This helps the immune system produce antibodies that can protect the body for a longer period of time.

Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna both work with messenger RNA (mRNA) technology. This technology triggers the body's own immune system to produce an antibody to fight off the virus.

The Johnson & Johnson vaccine works with a similar technology, but does not use mRNA.

Who is being offered the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine?

People in the UK are being offered the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.

How do you register to get the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine?

People in the UK are being offered the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. You will need to register online to book a place.

Who's being offered the Moderna vaccine?

People in the UK are being offered the Moderna vaccine.

How do you register to get the Moderna vaccine?

People in the UK are being offered the Moderna vaccine. You will need to register online to book a place.

What do you know about the Johnson & Johnson vaccine?

The Johnson & Johnson vaccine uses the same technology as Pfizer-BioNTech. However, it uses the same mRNA technology as a different vaccine.

How does the Johnson & Johnson vaccine work?

The Johnson & Johnson vaccine uses the same technology as Pfizer-BioNTech to trigger the immune system's response to the coronavirus. It uses the same mRNA technology as a different vaccine.

Colonial Pipeline Co.'s cyberattack raises questions for oil, gas and security experts . Cybersecurity has been a serious concern for the industry in recent years . Experts and officials are working to help the oil and gas industry secure their IT systems in light of recent attacks . By . John Dougherty . For DailyFX .com . Posted on May 13, 2018 at 3:38 PM . The Colonial Pipeline Co. cyberattack raises questions for both oil and gas security experts and government officials about the resilience of the industry to future cyberattacks. On Monday, the company's automated systems shut down because of an unknown malware infection. The shutdown disrupted fuel supply on the East Coast, causing government action and uncertainty in fuel prices and supplies. The cybersecurity experts and officials are attempting to help the oil and gas industry . The Colonial cyberattack significantly disrupted fuel supply on the East Coast, causing government action and uncertainty in fuel prices and supplies . The Colonial pipeline is one of several major U.S. oil, gas and pipeline firms to have suffered a cyberattack in the past year . In a statement released on Tuesday, U.S. Deputy National Security Advisor Anne Neuberger mentioned efforts to protect the IT systems of companies such as Colonial. "We will continue to assess new threats to our infrastructure and to work with industry and other government officials to prevent ransomware from moving to operational technology systems," she said. "We will continue to keep U.S. consumers safe and ensure the security of critical infrastructure." The FBI and Department of Homeland Security said in the statement that the agency is working with the companies to identify those responsible for the cyberattack and to resolve the incident . Cybersecurity experts warn that the increase in connected legacy assets and ransomware heightens the risk of physical infrastructure shutdowns . Industry . experts advocate for better visibility and defense-in-depth strategies to respond more precisely to cyberattacks . These . experts and officials are . working . to help the oil and gas industry . secure their . IT systems . in light of recent attacks . The FBI and Department of Homeland Security said in the statement that the . agency is working with the companies to identify those responsible for the cyberattack . and to resolve the . incident . "This... Cyberattacks . have caused a significant number of major . U.S. companies . to shut down in the past . year and are expected to increase in the coming years . Security . professionals warn that the increase in connected legacy assets and . ransomware heightens the risk of physical infrastructure shutdowns .

As vice president, Joe Biden chose Kamala Harris to help oversee efforts to end migration from Central America into the United States. But will her efforts to manage the United States southern border be enough to stem the flow of more than a quarter of a million migrants into the US each year? As the nation's second-highest-ranking Hispanic, and the first female president-elect, Joe Biden chose Harris in hopes that she could help turn the focus away from managing border security issues, and toward addressing the root causes of migration from Central America, which is often driven by poverty and economic opportunity, and the political instability that often accompanies it. "It is important for us to focus on the root causes of migration, rather than managing the southern border," Harris told ABC News. "Poverty is a big factor, and instability in these countries is a huge factor." While Biden's team is preparing to head to Mexico and Guatemala next week, the former California senator is worried about political entanglement in any immigration policy discussions with Mexican officials. Critics from the Republican majority have accused Joe Biden's team, led by Harris, of turning their back on the country to work on border issues. "They have turned their backs on the nation and are focused on dealing with the border," Sen. Ted Cruz said on a recent radio show. In the wake of this, Harris and other officials are preparing to travel to the countries of Guatemala and Mexico to discuss ways to stem the migration from their countries. The former San Francisco attorney general said she is not worried about the possible political ramifications of the trip. "Politics is not my area," Harris said. "I have a responsibility to be doing what I can in my position to resolve these problems that are very real." In the wake of the announcement, Republican critics have accused Joe Biden's team, led by Harris, of turning their back on the country to work on border issues. "The president-elect should be focusing his attention on governing the country and not on dealing with a border crisis," Sen. Ted Cruz said on a recent radio show. "We have our own border issues to deal with." "The president-elect should be focusing his attention on governing the country and not on dealing with a border crisis," said Sen. Ted Cruz. "We have our own border issues to deal with." In addition to a trip to the northern Triangle countries, Harris is expected to make a trip to Mexico this week to meet with Mexican President-elect Andrés Manuel López Obrador. The former San Franciscans attorney general said she is not worried about the possible political ramifications of the trip.

A third batch of California stimulus checks is on the way. This new batch will be sent out on October 5, and those who receive it will get their money in the form of a paper check as well as a direct deposit . It's still unknown how many Californians will receive the money, but it's estimated it will reach up to 2 million and 600,000 people, per the LA Times . It's also unknown what the size of the new batch will be, but it was the second largest stimulus payment in California history . The third and final round of checks will follow the first two waves, which included 1 million and 600,000 Californians who received $216 per person . In total, about 9 million people are estimated to be eligible for these checks . (CNN)California's third round of stimulus payments will be sent out next week. The new batch will be mailed out in addition to direct deposits, according to the California Department of Finance. So far, two separate rounds have been sent to California residents. The first batch was mailed out in August and sent to 1 million and 600,000 people. The second batch was mailed out in September and sent to another 1 million and 600,000 people, per CNNMoney. California Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that California's next round of stimulus payments will be mailed out on Oct. 5 in a briefing on Monday. The department announced that the third round is estimated to cost about $500 million, per the Los Angeles Times. The second round was the largest in California's history, the LA Times reported. Newsom said that about 9 million people will be eligible for the next round of checks, which will be mailed out on Oct. 5. That's roughly equal to about 2 million and 600,000 people, per CNN. The first two rounds of checks included 1 million and 600,000 people in the first batch; 1 million and 600,000 people in the second batch. Both checks were $216 per person. The third round will follow the first two waves, which included 1 million and 600,000 Californians who received checks of $16 apiece.

US bank giant and digital payments platform Venmo is offering check cashing for stimulus payments. Venmo is also waiving fees for cashing government payments, so that users of its app can access their stimulus funds without a cut.

The Venmo app is already a popular tool for cashing government payments, such as SNAP (food stamps) and SSI. However, Venmo has yet to provide cash-back for the second round of stimulus payments being delivered to eligible US adults via direct deposit, paper checks, and EIP cards. Users will be able to access their payments with a verification email, Venmo debit card, or active direct deposit, and location services, including GPS and Wi-Fi. They can also deposit the money directly onto their bank account.

Venmo has partnered with First Century Bank and Insign Money to offer cash-back from the government's second round of payments. The feature is being rolled out across the US.

In fact, Venmo, which is owned by PayPal, is waiving fees on the cash-back feature. This is the first time a major bank and payments service have worked together to provide an app feature. Venmo's partnership with First Century Bank allows its users to withdraw cash from any bank within the network, rather than just First Century Bank. First Century also provides customers with debit cards that can be used with Venmo to cash checks.

Venmo has been trying to grow its mobile payments presence across the US, and the new feature will further expand the utility of this tool for cash-back from government stimulus payments. Venmo users can use their Venmo debit cards to cash checks, or deposit the money directly onto their bank account. It also allows users to withdraw cash from any bank within the network, rather than just First Century Bank. As such, Venmo is starting to take on some of the more established mobile wallets, such as Apple Pay, which only works with Apple Pay on Apple devices. With the new partnership with First Century Bank, Venmo will no longer need to rely on one partner for its cashing of government checks.

Vaccine hesitancy in the United States has reached a new low.

The vast majority of people who are apprehensive about getting vaccinated against COVID-19 have done so in recent weeks, according to a survey by Kaiser Family Foundation released on Monday.

The survey finds 44% of U.S. adults said they hesitated to get vaccinated in March. That's an increase from 37% in December, when the survey started. And, as of March 1, about 50 million U.S. residents had received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine.

In the poll, which was conducted from December 15 to 23, and released on Monday, 47% of U.S. adults said they were sure or somewhat certain they would get vaccinated. That's a big jump from 21% in December and 25% in January.

The survey does not count people who are unsure about the safety of the vaccines.

The poll found people who were unsure about the vaccines were most likely to be in the age group of 25 to 34 years old, with a woman being most likely to be unsure about the vaccines.

In comparison, in December, 34% of U.S. adults who were unsure about the vaccines were in the age group of 25 to 34, with a woman being most likely to be unsure about the vaccines.

The survey also asked whether the person had been advised by a doctor to get vaccinated. Of those who said they were not advised to get vaccinated, 42% said they were unsure about the vaccines, while 21% said they were sure or somewhat certain not to get vaccinated.

The survey also asked about age and gender differences among those hesitant to get vaccinated. For example, 45% of men said they were not advised to get vaccinated, compared to 37% of women, and 56% of those not advised to get vaccinated were in the age group of 25 to 34, compared to 34% of those not advised to get vaccinated in the age group of 65 and older.

Rittenhouse's acquittal on Monday night was widely praised, with many calling for him to receive an award for his actions, while Kyle Shalikashvili's conviction on Tuesday night was met with outrage. These are the diverging outcomes of two cases that have prompted an important debate about the right of Americans to defend themselves and how laws of self-defense apply to civilians and the police. The girls, Mina and Ahmad Faisal, have arrived in Boston, Massachusetts and Seattle, Washington, respectively. They suffered serious injuries to their limbs and were badly burned, their aunt Ferishta said. The girls' father and brother were separated from them in the chaos of the explosion, Ferishta said. The girls are part of a group of 14 Afghan boys and girls who have arrived in the US for treatment, according to the State Department. Ferishta, who fled the attack in Kabul airport with her family in 2013 to avoid the Taliban, said she has not seen her children for three years. In the chaos of the explosion, the girls were separated from their father and brother, and their mother died, she said. The bomb, which killed at least 29 people in a busy airport, was believed to be an ISIS-K bomber.
