The House of Representatives has impeached President Trump on two counts: one charge of abusive behaviour and the other of threatening the integrity of the US election. There is no doubt Donald Trump will lose his presidency on the first count, which is abuse of office. But his lawyers have had to work hard to try to convince senators that they have not lost their sense of fairness or impartiality. Trump's lawyers say he was acting within the limits of the constitution in firing Comey as FBI director, in firing his generals and in imposing travel restrictions on foreign nationals in the US. But they will be looking to add a third count: that the impeachment process was unconstitutional. So why do 43 Republican senators vote to convict President Trump? They believe that what the House Managers did not do was establish a clear and present danger to the national security, or that the conduct of Trump had been so egregious that impeachment was the only way forward. The question is why are 43 Republican senators in the Senate voting not to convict Trump? They believe that what the House Managers did not do was establish a clear and present danger to the national security, or that the conduct of Trump had been so egregious that impeachment was the only way forward. Senator Rand Paul said that Trump is a "very dangerous" person, but that the Trump administration is "very much alive", so he has no choice but to vote not to impeach Trump. Why are 43 Republican senators not in favour of convicting Trump? They believe the conduct of Trump is not so egregious that impeachment is the only way forward.

The Daily Press is accepting comments on the following story: It may be nearly three years since Kyle Rittenhouse was convicted in a Kenosha, Wis., trial, but the case against the 18-year-old is not yet over.

And not only because he has not been sentenced, which could take years. More than that, he has been acquitted of killing three people at a protest in October 2020.

That doesn't mean Kyle Rittenhouse is out of the woods, but it does mean that the trial that led to his convictions, which featured impassioned testimony by his lawyer and emotional testimony by himself, is not going to get repeated anytime soon.

After the three-year standoff, this week the Wisconsin court decided to set aside the trial verdict because the jury acquitted Kyle Rittenhouse of killing three people at a Kenosha, Wis., protest, according to court documents obtained by the Wisconsin State Journal.

The court also dismissed all charges against Rittenhouse and released him from prison.

The trial verdict was overturned because of the jury's refusal to accept Kyle Rittenhouse's testimony during the trial, which he described as emotional.

It was something different from what occurred during the three-day trial of the former outlaw biker, which was called a miscarriage of justice by the defense attorney for Kyle Rittenhouse.

Wisconsin Gov. Tony Evers has called on the Wisconsin State Journal to publish the verdicts, saying they could lead to an investigation of the Kenosha Police Department's conduct of the original investigation. Rittenhouse's lawyer also said that he was confident his client would be acquitted again, and now that Kyle Rittenhouse is no longer under criminal arrest, it's time for him to get a fair trial. "He's been proven wrong, and I think he's going to go through this process, and he's going to get his day in court," Kyle Rittenhouse's lawyer, Mark Feldman, said in September. In it, the 18-year-old was depicted as a hero, receiving praise from singer-songwriter Ted Nugent and right-wing gun-rights activists. In an interview with Fox 5, Nugent said Kyle Rittenhouse "showed the true face of the white supremacy and the white nationalist" in Kenosha, Wis. "It's a pretty good day for Rittenhouse," he said. Nugent also told the station that he was confident Kyle would be exonerated. "I hope not, but I know there's no reason he shouldn't," Nugent said. Rittenhouse has been called a hero by right-wing gun-rights activists and praised by singer-songwriter Ted Nugent. Click for Nugent's comments on Rittenhouse's acquittal.

President Donald Trump is banned from Facebook for two years Facebook is suspending Donald Trump's account in the wake of the riots at the US Capitol on January 6 . A fireworks display on Inauguration Day that was created by Chicago-based company Strictly FX was a big hit at Joe Biden and Kamala Harris's inauguration ceremony.

Read More

The team at Strictly FX, founded in Chicago in 1996, designed the fireworks display that was used at the Joe Biden-Harris Inauguration Day celebration. The show featured about 20,000 shells and a choreographed routine to Katy Perry's "Firework." The fireworks were launched in two launch zones in front of the new US president and vice president.

Adam Biscow, the designer from Strictly FX, emphasized the collaborative effort behind the show and the desire to create a memorable piece of history:

"We were so passionate about this, and we really wanted to use the opportunity to connect with the city and be part of the big picture."

A Strictly FX fireworks display was one of the highlights of the Joe Biden-Harris Inauguration Day celebration.

The team at Strictly FX worked to create an event that would be both memorable for Biden and Harris but also be safe for attendees. They designed the show with safe launch zones for the fireworks to launch in and with cameras to be able to capture everything. The show was choreographed to Katy Perry's performance of "Firework," and was a big hit at the inauguration ceremony.

President Joe Biden honored 13 US troops killed in an attack on an Afghan base last week with a solemn transfer ceremony at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware on Thursday. The ceremony took place amid criticism about Biden's handling of the exit from Afghanistan, which began last September, and also amid questions about the timing of Biden's visit to the UK to see his son. The troops were among the 130 who died in the attack on a base near Kabul airport last week, according to Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin. The members of the US military lost their lives when gunmen opened fire at a truck on March 1. The gunmen, believed to be Afghan, were killed during a gunfight with US troops, according to the Pentagon. Biden also visited the UK, where he is meeting the Queen of the UK, and met with foreign secretary Dominic Raab in London on Thursday. NEW: Judge rejects Kyle Rittenhouse defense request for use-of-force expert testimony NEW: Judge says prosecutors must show how to prove motive in pre-trial hearing . Kyle Rittenhouse has pleaded not guilty to three charges of first-degree murder, manslaughter and a fourth charge of criminal mischief . Rittenhouse remains in the Kenosha Police Department after his arrest on Dec. 1 . A judge has ruled against the defense request to have a use-of-force expert testify at trial . The hearing at the Kenosha Circuit Court was set for Oct. 21 . Rittenhouse is accused of killing two people and injuring an additional three during a mob attack . (CNN) A judge denied a request by the defense Tuesday to have a use-of-force expert testify at trial for Kyle Rittenhouse, the 17-year-old accused of killing two people and injuring three others during a mob attack in Kenosha, Wis., last month. Prosecutors asked that the expert examine Rittenhouse's handling of the weapons used in the incident, including an officer's gun, as evidence in the case against the teenager. The request was denied Tuesday in a brief ruling by Kenosha County Circuit Judge Bruce Schroeder. Rittenhouse has pleaded not guilty to three charges of first-degree murder, manslaughter and a fourth charge of criminal mischief . Schroeder said prosecutors must submit a written request in a pretrial hearing on Oct. 21 to show how to prove Rittenhouse's motive. The case against him will start on Nov. 1. Authorities said Kyle Rittenhouse fired several rounds at people during a mob attack last month, killing one man and injuring two women . At the time of the attack, the Rittenhouse Police Department was preparing to defend itself in response to a white supremacist rally that was being held in downtown Kenosha. The officers were defending themselves and their equipment, prosecutors said. The Kenosha County Circuit Judge Bruce Schroeder's ruling Tuesday denied the defense's request . Schroeder rejected the defense request Tuesday . He said the request was without merit, noting that the experts have already given evidence of Rittenhouse's actions in the police department during his time there and in training . Schroeder ruled on Tuesday that the prosecutors must show how they can prove Rittenhouse's motive in a pre-trial hearing scheduled for Oct. 21. If there is no evidence of Rittenhouse's motive, the case could be dismissed, Schroeder said . The judge also rejected the defense's request to introduce evidence about one of the victims that was later found in Rittenhouse's possession .

This is the most aggressive action the social media companies have taken against Trump, and he has been largely silent on Twitter since the storming. Trump's account is now effectively blocked from Twitter for at least 12 hours Trump will be removed from Twitter for at least 12 hours until his account is reinstated. A blood drive for shooting victims is hosted near a gun store parking lot. In the wake of the mass shootings in Michigan earlier this month, blood banks across the U.S. were encouraged to host blood drive events in their communities, but Bass Pro Shop in Fort Smith, Arkansas, has chosen to organize one near a store that sells firearms similar to those used in the school shooting. The blood drive was held Thursday night at Bass Pro Shop in the downtown area. The store is just south of the school shooting at an elementary school in Auburn Hills, Michigan, where 26 people were killed. They were gunned down in March over the weekend, and authorities there are searching for a suspect. "We felt it was appropriate to step up as a blood bank to help the families in Auburn Hills," Arkansas Blood Institute Executive Director Mark Schultz said in a statement. The press release for the event notes, "Auburn Hills is a town of some 13,000 that is served by the Fort Smith hospital, which is the only hospital in the city." Bass Pro Shop, a popular fishing and hunting equipment retailer, is also a gun store. The news comes as a reminder of the controversy surrounding mass shootings and blood donation. Last year in New York City and Chicago, gun owners and advocates criticized mass blood drive events that were held in their respective neighborhoods. The group Gun Violence Archive, which tracks gun violence in the U.S., says there have been more than 200 mass shootings in the U.S. this year, the most in at least eight years. While there are blood drive events across the country hosted by nonprofits and local hospitals, there is concern that, for many people, they are inconvenient and they have to drive to locations far from where they work or where they live. Critics say blood drive events provide a false sense of safety and make it easier for people to purchase guns online.

Arkansas blood drive is held near gun store parking lot, where sales of guns similar to those used in school shooting are conducted. Photo provided by Bass Pro Shop

For example, the gun store at Bass Pro Shop sells a .45-caliber semi-automatic rifle, which is similar to the one used in the Auburn Hills school shooting, according to the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF). The .45-caliber semi-automatic rifle, similar to one used in Auburn Hills shooting, can be purchased from Bass Pro Shop. The FBI is investigating the Auburn Hills school shooting, which killed at least 24 students, teachers and staff. Gun violence continues to be a growing problem across the U.S., according to Gun Violence Archive.

Citibank has admitted it paid millions of dollars to lenders after an internal employee accidentally transferred $1.1bn (Â£760m) from Revlon to a Citibank account as interest payments. The error occurred during a $894m (Â£668m) Revlon loan, which Citibank said a mistake in a simple user interface meant the transaction was processed as if it were interest payments. The 'three-eyed policy' meant a Wipro employee had to be in control of the transaction and a local manager in India needed to approve it, but a mistake was made by Wipro staff who did the actual transaction to pay the $894m principal to Revlon's 315 creditors earlier than its due date in 2023, Citibank said in a statement. Citibank said it had taken steps to avoid similar mistakes in the future, such as a six-eyes policy; a local manager and staff in India need to approve loans with a foreign parent. Wipro, which provides IT services to Citibank and many of its customers, is an Indian company with over two million employees. A Citibank spokeswoman said: "We have apologised to our customers, the public and Wipro for this mistake and have taken steps to ensure that similar mistakes do not occur in the future." The Citibank spokesperson did not respond to requests to comment further on the three-eyed policy, which was used to justify the error.

The Washington Post has the story of one escapee, Sara Qaderi, who was able to board a flight to Qatar, from where she was evacuated to the US on Saturday. It is her story of desperation and survival during the airlift operation and her journey from Taliban-controlled Kabul to Qatar. Tens of thousands of Afghans working with the US and other countries tried to escape Kabul over the weekend, but most ended up trapped on the tarmac. A convoy of airlift planes carrying the first flight of evacuees to the US was held up on the runway at Kabul International Airport on Saturday by a mob of gun-wielding supporters of the Afghan government, and was forced to return to the airport. More than 200 passengers from the Qatar flight are being flown back to the US on other flights. More than 10,000 people have been evacuated from Kabul since the start of Saturday, the US military said. They have been flown to Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, the Netherlands, Japan, Egypt, Pakistan, Denmark and Germany, according to military officials. We need to talk about how we could be doing better to help our partners.

The Department of Homeland Security is investigating a recent series of cyber attacks on government and private organisations across the world. Both the U.S. and the U.S. Agency For International Development are investigating the attacks, which were initiated through an email marketing account of the U.S. Agency For International Development (USAID). The attacks appear to be a direct response to recent U.S. cyber attacks targeting foreign governments, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency announced on Wednesday, citing recent reports of suspected Russian government activity in a series of attacks on U.S. government websites. The cybersecurity incident comes just days after Microsoft announced the discovery of a new zero-day software security hole in its operating system. The hole has been discovered by U.S. researchers during a routine scan.

We are still waiting to find out who responsible for the attacks, and whether they were a direct response to the SolarWinds attacks in 2020, officials said. And whether the attackers targeted specific organizations, for example by targeting U.S. military bases in the Middle East, is unclear. But one thing is clear: this is the latest in a series of major hacking attacks that began in the spring of 2020 and have only grown in scale in the past year, according to the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency. Threat: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security has yet to confirm or deny any of the attacks are related to the SolarWinds hack, but the agency's statement on Wednesday said that it was investigating the cybersecurity incident . Terrorist groups often use hacking as a form of warfare, but this is the first reported instance of hacking being used to attack specific U.S. government agencies on behalf of a nation state . Alec Baldwin's lawyer says she is confident that the shooting that left actress Halyna Hutchins dead on the set of the film 'Rust' was accidental.

As the world's largest sovereign nation, the United States can play an important role in fostering international cyber security, especially in the wake of cyberattacks that shut down major infrastructure last week. This is a growing threat that must be addressed by the Trump administration and the Biden team. Cybersecurity expert Lisa Donnan, the managing director and chief security and risk officer of the cybersecurity firm Cybereason, experienced the consequences of an internal cybersecurity breach in Colonial Pipeline after a cyber-attack in May. She spoke to Dr. John Moore about how the company responded to the breach, the growing threat, and how the US can lead the charge in addressing it. Cybercriminals increasingly target critical infrastructure and services, including U.S. oil and gas operations. John Moore: We have seen a dramatic rise in ransomware attacks in the U.S. over the last couple of years, and there's been a dramatic increase in ransomware attacks in North America, particularly since the beginning of this year. What we've seen in the past few weeks with Colonial Pipeline was a stark reminder of the gravity of the problem, the potential consequences, and the escalating nature of the threat.

Vice President Kamala Harris will deliver remarks at the U.N. General Assembly on Tuesday . The speech comes as more U.S. is getting vaccinated . Kamala Harris, the first woman and first South Asian U.S. vice president, will make her remarks to the UN General Assembly . The speakers will stress the global need to work on pandemic response plans . The speech is Harris' second to a UN body since her inauguration . (CNN) The United Nations will be watching closely Tuesday as the first woman vice president of the U.S., Kamala Harris, delivers her first official speech to the world's largest gathering of countries and their leaders since she was sworn into office earlier this year. In her second speech at the United Nations General Assembly, Kamala Harris will call for a global response to the coronavirus pandemic and highlight the U.S. commitment to the global health community, CNN reports. The speech comes on the heels of the U.S.'s success in vaccinating its population against Covid-19, which now totals more than 20 million, and as more countries struggle with vaccine shortages, reports CNN's Jane Mayer. The U.S. has become the largest nation in the world to vaccinate all its adults against the disease, according to a tracker by the World Health Organization. "We're going to need to strengthen our global partnership to deliver the vaccines to all those who need them, especially in the developing world, where the virus is taking its toll," Harris said Monday in an interview with the AFP news agency. "We are going to need to make vaccines available to all who need them." Harris will make her remarks Tuesday at 10 a.m. ET, marking the first time a U.S. vice president has addressed the General Assembly since her swearing in earlier this year, reports CNN. Harris will address the General Assembly during a joint session co-hosted by Argentina, Japan, Norway and South Africa. A gun discharged on a film set in New Mexico, killing one person and injuring another . Cast and crew were rehearsing a scene after lunch on the Bonanza Creek Ranch set in Santa Fe when the incident happened . An assistant director handed the prop gun to Baldwin, who played a character with the gun, and reportedly said it was a 'cold gun' implying it was unloaded . 911 calls regarding the accidental shooting led to the confusion that the gun was unloaded . Alec Baldwin's agent confirmed the actor had been shot but did not give details of the shooting's severity, calling the incident a 'mistake' and a 'frustration of the law' for the actor and other cast and crew . A police report indicates that the gun was loaded when the incident happened but no charges have been filed against the director, cinematographer and another actor . Police have not responded to our request for comment .

On Wednesday, the House began the second impeachment trial for former President Donald Trump for "incitement of insurrection" after he urged his followers to storm the US Capitol on Jan. 6 . The trial included over 140,000 words in the record, with the impeachment managers speaking over 91,000 of those words, and Trump's lawyers contributing 33,000, the Washington Post reported . Impeachment managers also spoke more than four times as much as Trump's lawyers during the trial of his previous impeachment trial . Trump's lawyers spoke about 21,000 words in the first trial . The House's vote Wednesday to begin the trial included a bipartisan agreement to start the proceedings on a Thursday, meaning Trump would be in the room to defend himself . In an effort to prevent Trump's supporters from breaking into the Capitol, the House Speaker's office said that it would be a "safer place" for Trump to be if he remained inside his mansion at Mar-a-Lago, Florida . The second impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump for "incitement of insurrection" has been set to take place in the House of Representatives . Trump supporters stormed the US Capitol on Jan. 6 in an attempt to stop Congress from certifying the results of the November election .

NEW: A 13-year-old student is accused of threatening to shoot up his school's library on Wednesday . A high school student is arrested in Reading, Pennsylvania, for threatening a school with a gun . The student is charged with inducing panic and will be arraigned today . On Thursday the schools were closed due to a potential threat of violence from the student . He is part of the National Honor Society . Attorney General Kathleen Rice said the threat was a hoax created by the National Honor Society . By . Nathan Folsom. A 13-year-old student from Reading, Pennsylvania, was arrested and charged with threatening to open fire at Reading High School's library on Wednesday, according to police. The student, who was part of the National Honor Society, was arraigned in Hamilton County Juvenile Court on Thursday, reports the Reading Eagle. Prosecutors say the threat was made in the context of a dispute between the student and another student, who has since been charged with the same offence. This was the second school threat in Reading in as many days. Earlier this week, a 13-year-old student threatened to shoot up a library at his high school in the city. That student was charged with the same offence, inducing panic, and was ordered held at the Hamilton County Juvenile Court Youth Center. The student has since been indicted on a hate crime charge. 'He's part of a national honour society and the honour society does not exist in Pennsylvania,' the student's attorney said. A suicide bomber has detonated his explosives at a memorial service for a Taliban official in Kabul, killing at least five people, Afghan officials say. The four-wheel drive jeep in which the suicide bomber was travelling exploded outside the Eid Gah Mosque, a popular mosque in the capital, officials said. Afghan forces rushed to the scene and arrested three men over the attack, officials said. Reports suggest that an ISIS-K militant is behind the attack, which took place around 5am local time (0230 GMT on Friday). The ISIS-K are a faction of the jihadist group ISIS that were previously affiliated with the so-called Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) group. Suicide bombers have been targeting the nation's mosques in recent years, particularly after the group's withdrawal from many major cities in Iraq and Syria. The bombing comes just a week after ISIS-K militants killed nine people in an attack on a police station north of the capital in Kabul, the police said. Five people were killed and four others were wounded in a suicide attack outside the Eid Gah mosque in Kabul, Afghanistan, officials said. ISIS-K militants have been targeting Afghan mosques, particularly after the group's withdrawal from Iraq and Syria.

George Floyd's family released a statement Tuesday, calling Floyd's death a "heartbreaking accident." The family said they "would like to reiterate that we do not believe that George Floyd's death was a result of misconduct by Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin." The statement comes as prosecutors presented the closing arguments in the trial of Chauvin, who has been accused of murder. It was the last day of testimony at the grand jury on Monday and Tuesday and is expected to be heard in full on Tuesday and Wednesday. In the statement, the family of Floyd says the death of Floyd on May 25 was a "heartbreaking accident," and they would "not have it any other way." Floyd's family said they "would like to reiterate that we do not believe that George Floyd's death was a result of misconduct by Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin." Photo from AP shows the police officer kneeling on George Floyd's neck . Prosecutors and defense attorneys presented closing arguments on Monday and Tuesday . The prosecution rests its case and the defense is expected to present its closing arguments in full on Tuesday and Wednesday . The defense is expected to ask the jury to find the police officer not guilty on all charges of murder, manslaughter, and involuntary manslaughter .

Tiger Woods is returning to competitive golf for the first time since a serious car crash in February, the New York Daily News reports. The world No. 1, who was playing in the PNC Championship in Charlotte, North Carolina, Sunday, is recovering from serious injuries sustained in a crash with his son Charlie. Woods, 45, was seriously injured when his SUV rolled over a median and ended up in a ravine in a wooded area in California. The car crash is one of the greatest personal tragedies in golf history, and Woods' recovery has not come without challenges. The source, who is close to Woods' family, said Tiger Woods is focused on making a full recovery and is 'very pleased' to be back playing golf with his son, Charlie. The news comes weeks after Tiger Woods announced plans to retire as a professional golfer. The PNC Championship will be the last tournament Woods plays in before the end of the 2016 season. Tiger Woods is back in the game, playing with his son Charlie at the PNC Championship in Charlotte, North Carolina, Sunday evening. The former Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum has resigned from CNN following his remarks about Native Americans . The comments about the Native Americans had been made in a speech to a conservative youth group in April of this year . But Santorum still maintained his defense of the remarks in an interview with Cuomo Prime Time . Facebook's recent six-hour outage affected billions of users, causing the group's stock value to drop significantly . The death of George Floyd on May 25, 2020, sparked a nationwide protest over police brutality, led by protests in Minnesota, where Floyd died after being seized by police officer Derek Chauvin. Fellow officer Tou Thao was arrested for assisting Chauvin in the arrest of George Floyd, a black man who was unconscious and struggling to breathe. On August 1, the Minneapolis City Council voted unanimously to rename George Floyd Square, marking the square as a memorial for Floyd, and the movement's new headquarters as well as a place to honor all lives lost to police brutality. The story of George Floyd's death is still unfolding and will not be resolved soon, but the following key points are worth recalling.

Floyd died in Minneapolis police custody after Derek Chauvin knelt on his neck for nine minutes. pic.twitter.com/yKz6UyQ6xU Chauvin was sentenced to a minimum of 22.5 years and a maximum of 39 years in prison, and the sentence will run concurrently with the 25 years for his murder conviction.

The other three officers involved in Floyd's death were arrested on charges of aiding and abetting in the murder, manslaughter and involuntary manslaughter. None of the officers are currently serving prison time because the charges are classified as misdemeanor. George Floyd Square will remain as a memorial and movement headquarters, and will remain open to the public for years to come.

The trial of the three other officers involved is forthcoming with federal indictments handed down against all four.

Prosecutors say Kyle Rittenhouse sought violent situations to commit further acts of violence after striking an unarmed 17-year-old girl in Kenosha on July 1 last year. Kyle Rittenhouse's past violent actions will be considered in his trial for the fatal shooting of two men and wounding another . Rittenhouse, 18, was charged with the shootings of two men and wounding one during protests after police killed Jacob Blake in Wisconsin last year . Wisconsin prosecutors want to introduce evidence of Rittenhouse's past violent incident in his trial . The video was taken in a shopping centre in Kenosha in July 2020 . The video shows Rittenhouse striking a teenage girl . The girl was standing in the aisle near the entrance to the shopping centre . She is seen falling backwards as Rittenhouse punches her, kicking her and slams her on the ground . Prosecutors said Rittenhouse struck the teenager to justify his actions . Rittenhouse has been charged with the fatal shootings of two men and wounding one during police brutality protests in Kenosha last year .

Facebook employees abused access to user data to track down co-workers who went on vacation, a new book claims. Facebook employees abused access to user data to track down co-workers who went on vacation and harass their former colleagues in a new book, reports BBC Newsbeat. An Ugly Truth: Inside Facebook's Battle for Domination is written by author and former Facebook engineer Jeff Sutter. Facebook is facing a growing backlash over its handling of its own data, particularly in relation to mass surveillance. He claims that engineers abused access to Facebook user data to locate co-workers who'd gone on vacation. Sutter says that Facebook granted engineers 'extensive data access' to streamline their work, which meant that they could 'manipulate data to track people' in an attempt to 'get revenge on their former colleagues'. The book claims that staff were able to access Facebook's internal logs and other corporate data 'without risk of being caught' by Facebook's security policies. They were able to track people to their new hotel rooms, and even access their conversations and real-time location, reports the BBC. The book claims that staff were able to access Facebook's internal logs and other corporate data 'without risk of being caught' by Facebook's security policies.

Hurricane Ida caused extensive damage across Louisiana on Monday, including the loss of an oyster farm in Houma, about 30 miles west of Baton Rouge. Now, Louisiana is struggling to rebuild and adapt in the wake of the disaster, which also caused widespread flooding in southern parts of the state, including Orleans Parish, which saw more than 100,000 people evacuated to shelters after flooding and debris washed ashore in areas such as Baton Rouge Bayou. The Associated Press visited a seafood market in Lafayette on Tuesday to look at how Hurricane Ida's impact has affected the state as well as the local business community. Here is the AP's report on the Louisiana seafood industry following Hurricane Ida. Click to expand the image. Louisiana has a $2.4 billion seafood industry employing more than 23,000 people. Hundreds of people have been evacuated in Orleans Parish after Hurricane Ida. The state has seen extensive flooding since Friday and large portions of Baton Rouge and Orleans Parishes are still without power, with some areas still under flood waters. Louisiana's seafood industry, worth $2.4 billion and employing over 23,000, faces challenges in recovery and adaptation. Motivatit Seafoods in Houma suffered immense damage, with substantial impacts on oyster production already strained by past events. In Baton Rouge, the city was flooded to the second floor after more than 100,000 people were evacuated Monday.

Amazon suspended its cloud services to Parler post-pandemic on Sunday . The move by Amazon, one of the world's largest tech companies, could possibly shut down Parler without a new cloud provider . Amazon said in a statement that the platform would not be available until Parler removed the violent incitement posts it was carrying under the guise of free speech . Parler's CEO John Matze called the move by Amazon a "victory for democracy" and said Amazon, Google, and Apple are colluding to eliminate competition . On Thursday, Parler announced that it signed a $500 million contract to bring in a new financial backer as a part of efforts to get the site back online . 'Free speech' Parler, a social network known for its conservative views, was popular among those who protested against President Donald Trump's efforts to overturn the election . By . John O'Donnell . Amazon has suspended Amazon Web Services (AWS) service from the far-right social network Parler. Parler has been using AWS to host the site since 2016. Amazon announced the suspension on its website today, which does not specifically state why it has suspended AWS service, but in a statement said that Parler had failed to comply with the terms of use of AWS, and would no longer be able to use AWS until the site complies with the terms. The suspended service is crucial for Parler, because Parler is currently unable to move its website to a different hosting service, as Amazon's decision could shut down the site without a new cloud provider, meaning all of Parler's users would lose their accounts. Parler's CEO, John Matze, responded to the news of Amazon's decision to ban Parler from its cloud services. He told CNBC that Amazon, Google, and Apple are colluding to eliminate competition. 'It is clear to all that Parler, which has long been the darling of the alt-right community, was the first and only true alternative to Facebook and Twitter. Amazon and the rest of the tech giants are trying to suppress innovation and free speech. We will fight back. It is a victory for democracy, and a victory for the free-speech movement,' Matze said. He added that the tech giants are only doing this for the profits that Amazon makes from the advertising they can place on Parler's site. Amazon said that users of Parler will no longer be able to use Parler unless they delete the violent incitement posts the site currently carries, and Amazon has stated that it is willing to negotiate with Parler on a deal to remove the posts. Parler was popular among those who protested against President Donald Trump's efforts to overturn the election, which led to a storm of violence at the U.S. Capitol on January 6.

Media coverage of a missing woman has reignited discussions on 'missing white woman syndrome' Last September, news of an Amazon prime video sex video surfaced that was allegedly directed at a young black woman. As the case of Gabby Petito became a matter of national news, the focus on her race became especially prevalent. Journalists and public figures from across the ideological spectrum criticized media attention to her case, pointing out that it's a symptom of a longstanding problem in media storytelling. Why focus on her race, and how can race be a factor when reporting? Media coverage of missing women has focused on race disproportionately over the years, according to Chris Cuomo, who has been covering the case of missing woman, Gabby Petito, for the past three months. (Photo: Getty Images)

Gabby Petito, 23, from Idaho, went missing on August 3, 2017. She has been missing for almost five months. Her disappearance has been covered extensively in the media and has led to widespread public concern about her safety.

The case of Petito, whose disappearance sparked nationwide debate on the issue of missing white women, has received intense media coverage since her disappearance. The story has been reported by multiple outlets, including CNN, the Washington Post, Fox News, and the BBC. A number of politicians from both sides of the political spectrum have also shared their views on the case and have been critical of media coverage of Petito's disappearance.

In fact, the hashtag #missingwhitewomensyndrome has been trending on Twitter since Gabby Petito's disappearance, with millions of people sharing their opinions on the issue. The hashtag was started by the author and activist Lauren Berard in June of this year. As the name suggests, the hashtag highlights media's disproportionate focus on white female victims, neglecting victims of color.

The hashtag trending on Twitter has been criticized by journalists and public figures from across the ideological spectrum. Others have argued that the hashtag is actually a symptom of a larger problem in media coverage of missing women. According to a CNN article written by Lauren Berard and published last month, the term 'missing white woman syndrome' was coined by a woman who worked as a magazine editor when she was a teenager. She felt that media coverage of missing women was skewed by a focus on white women of a similar age to her, and often neglected cases of women of color.

The article explains that although the hashtag was coined by a teenager, the term was popularized by a news reporter. She used the term to explain how the news media's focus on missing women was a symptom of a larger problem in media coverage of missing women.

President Joe Biden's inauguration was filled with color, symbolism, tradition and history. Read about it in this article by Dr. Hillary Clinton. As I watch Joe Biden's inauguration, I am reminded of my own first presidential inauguration. I was standing in the rotunda on a rainy day in Washington, D.C., a few years ago when I watched my husband be sworn in as vice president. It was an extraordinary moment. I think about all the good that Joe Biden will do for the nation, but I also think about the future of our country. On the one hand, we knew that there were problems in the country. The country was going through a pandemic and racial unrest was at an all-time high. But on the other hand, I felt that we were on the road to recovery. I knew that Joe Biden's campaign would be tough, but the country was going to get through. I am confident that this will be just the beginning. This moment in time is very special, but I am also very aware of where we are. We are a country that was ravaged by the pandemic, we have racial unrest that is at an all-time high, and we have a deep, deep division. Joe Biden's administration will have to work hard to bring us back together. This is an historic moment for our country. And hopefully, it will create a moment of unification. Biden will have to break down walls. I think he will be able to do that. There will be many challenges ahead, and we need him to make sure that his administration is focused on fixing the problems that we all face. He has a long road ahead of him. Guru Maharaj Ji's Divine Light Mission, one of America's best-known and most influential religious movements, has experienced a stunning growth in the past few years, according to a recent New York Times profile of the group. Since its creation in the late 1970s, the mission has gained more than 1 million members, with an estimated 2 million people believed to practice its teachings, according to the Times' profile. "It has experienced a dramatic increase in the past few years, perhaps because of the stress of the present situation in the world," the article states. It notes that members of the mission often believe it can alleviate such current problems as poverty, war, racism, and terrorism. They believe that spirituality can be used to bring about personal and global transformation through spirituality. This article will cover how this mission has changed over the years and what it hopes to do for the future. Rennie Davis, a prominent antiwar activist during the Vietnam War, was one of the original leaders of the mission. In 1973, he switched his activism to the teachings of Guru Maharaj Ji, who advocated for the Divine Light Mission's teachings. He claims that activism and spirituality can help solve problems like war, poverty, and racism. Davis's involvement with Guru Maharaj Ji's Divine Light Mission marked a significant shift from his previous political work to a focus on personal and global transformation through spirituality.

The Washington Post: US Sen. Lindsey Graham wants Twitter to be like other businesses Graham is planning to challenge Twitter ban on President Trump Graham said Friday that Trump had the right to tweet as he did, but that Twitter should also face legal responsibility when it bans users for violating its terms of service . He also said that he believes that Twitter can be held accountable . Graham, R-S.C., would like to see companies, such as Twitter, forced to share their user information with the government if they violated privacy laws . (CNN) On Friday, U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham, a staunch Trump ally, announced he intends to challenge Twitter's recent ban of President Trump from posting on its platform. Graham said the move should not be viewed as a legal victory for Trump, but instead as a chance for the U.S. to take back control of what happens on social media. He told reporters that he would fight to restore Trump to Twitter and that the president's tweets would continue to be available to the public. On Tuesday, Twitter banned Trump from its platform indefinitely, saying he had engaged in violence against the country. Trump called the decision a "ridiculous attack" and a "slam dunk." Twitter has said the president violated its terms of service, including its ban on inciting violence. He said in a statement released on Twitter Friday that he had no doubt Twitter could be held accountable by the court if Trump violated its policies again. "This is what happens when you have absolute immunity from being sued," he said. Graham said he believes that Twitter can be held accountable for its actions, but that it shouldn't be "absolutely immune from being sued." He also argued that Twitter must share information with the government if companies violate privacy laws. "I think it's possible Twitter would do something similar to what Facebook did when Facebook was selling the data of its users to the political advertisers and campaign groups," he said. "If you can't trust a company, you don't use it."

On Monday, December 31, the IRS began distributing stimulus payments to Americans who have not yet received their first round but have a bank account with a US-based financial institution. What are these payments? Who gets them? How do you apply? What questions do you need to answer before you receive your checks? And how are they different from the first round of payments? Here are the answers to the most important questions you need to know about this new round of checks.

The second stimulus payments from the U.S. Treasury were first announced in March. Read more: The IRS said that payments will begin at the same time as last time, on Monday. If your account is not currently open with a bank in the U.S., the checks will be sent to your bank. If you have an account, you will receive the payment on the same schedule as the initial round: you will begin receiving payments on December 30, and you will be able to receive them through direct deposit beginning on January 4.

Here is what you need to know about your stimulus payments.

Who will get it?

The check will go to every eligible adult and dependent child under the age of 18 on file with the IRS on December 31. This includes individuals who are unmarried, separated, or divorced and who have an adult living with them.

The IRS is making these payments to individuals who have an account with a US-based financial institution. You should be able to check your status online using the "Get My Payment" website and check your status with your bank. If you have a bank account with a US-based financial institution and you are not listed on the IRS's list of eligible adults for the second round, the check will go to your bank account, not to the address on your income tax return. You will need to check with your bank about whether you qualify for a check or direct deposit. You should receive this first round of checks by mail, if you are not listed on the IRS's list of eligible adults for the second round. You will begin receiving them on December 30. What do you need to do before you get your checks?

You will need to be listed on the IRS's list of eligible adults for the second round on December 31. This is the list of individuals who are receiving the second round of checks. You can find it on the IRS's "Get My Payment" website. You will need to verify your income before receiving your stimulus payments. You can do this by making a free Federal Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) online using the IRS's "Free File" service.

The Green Bay Packers have reassigned quarterback Aaron Rodgers to the COVID-19 Reserve/COVID-19 list, effective immediately, according to the team's media relations office. The move follows the quarterback's positive test for the virus, the first to occur during the regular season this season. Rodgers, 25, is scheduled to start for Green Bay in Week 9 against the Kansas City Chiefs on Sunday.

The team confirmed on Sunday that the quarterback tested positive on March 27. The test came back positive for a strain of the coronavirus that has since been declared a disease by the World Health Organization.

"I was put into the (COVID-19) reserve list last week to see if I would be eligible to play, and I'm still eligible to play," Rodgers said in a statement released by the team. "My testing will continue, and I will continue my treatment. I am eager to get back on the sidelines and be back with the team."

Rodgers previously said that he had been vaccinated and that the antibodies he received from the shot provided protection against the illness. But after the testing positive on March 27, he decided to seek an exemption from the NFL's COVID-19 protocols based on his antibody levels. The request, made on March 27, was denied.

Rodgers underwent homeopathic treatment on the weekend to raise his antibodies, which the NFL, NFLPA, and infectious disease consultant did not recognize as valid protection. The NFLPA cited the treatment as being outside of the league's protocols, according to the league's official statement.

The Green Bay Packers did not respond to a question about whether the treatment had any effect on the Green Bay quarterback's testing result.

"At this stage, the information is sufficient for us to conclude that (homeopathy) did not have any effect on his positive test result," the NFLPA said in a statement released on Sunday.

Here is an edited transcript of an interview with Steven Clark, who has been working for Derek Chauvin's prosecution team, to discuss the challenges facing the defense in this case. In this interview, Clark says the lawyers on trial are trying to make the case for what they should and shouldn't be convicted of.

The transcript was provided to the Journal by Steven Clark. The Associated Press has not independently verified the accuracy of this transcript. Q: You were one of the first lawyers to work with the prosecutors in this case. How did you feel about the choice of the prosecution team? Steven Clark: I think they selected the right lawyers. Erin Eldridge and Matthew Frank are two very experienced attorneys that understand the criminal justice system. They have worked on many high-profile cases, including Eric Holder's and John Ashcroft's cases. They have tremendous experience. It was important for them to have a lot of experience on this case and to represent the interests of the government, which is the interest of all of us. There is a lot of attention being paid to how the trial is going because this is a high-profile case and it's important that it goes well for everyone. Q: How do you feel about the number of attorneys on trial? Do you think it's too large for the jurors to get a good sense of the individual attorneys? Steven Clark: I think it's the right number of attorneys. It's not a one-size-fits-all trial. I have never worked with a trial that had 10 or more attorneys on trial, so I don't know. I only know what I've seen in other trials. But the number of attorneys is what it is.

The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) has released a preliminary report on the causes of the winter freeze that hit Texas earlier this year, leading to hundreds of deaths and widespread power outages. The FERC report found that freezing and insufficient winterizing of generators contributed to 44% of the outage issues, followed by natural gas fuel shortages, which contributed to 31% of the issues. The 28 recommendations made by the FERC address issues related to generator winterization and training. Texas officials and residents are still searching for answers to events leading to the winter outage that left millions without power in Texas. The FERC report recommends that regulators, energy suppliers and the Texas Public Utility Commission conduct annual winterization training and equipment inspections to prevent future outages.

Texas officials say the freezing temperatures contributed to hundreds of deaths, left more than 700,000 without power, and led millions to take up to 6 hours to get power back on. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission released a report Thursday on the causes of what many call the worst blackout in US history. The 28 recommendations are focused on generator winterization, conducting annual winterization training, and monitoring pipeline temperatures. This image shows an outage street in Texas. Officials have been looking for answers to what led to the severe blackout, which many attribute to winter weather.

For years, regulators have tried to crack the mystery of why this happened. FERC released its findings Thursday, and regulators say they now know the main cause of the Texas blackout was "freezing or insufficient winterizing of generators," according to the FERC report. The findings say that 44% of the issues were due to freezing, while 31% were due to natural gas fuel shortages. But most natural gas production and processing facilities were not protected against load shedding, leading to a decline in supply. This picture shows a block of homes during the blackout. The joint chiefs of staff of the United States military have released a statement condemning the January 6, 2021, insurrection at the United States Capitol. It was signed by all eight members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. They described it as a direct assault on the U.S. Congress, the Capitol building, and the constitutional process.

President Trump called the uprising a hoax and claimed that his supporters were the victim of an "orchestrated insurrection" designed to overturn the election result, and then tried to storm the building. Authorities later arrested more than 100 people after the riot. The insurrection left five people dead, including a police officer, and more than 50 people with injuries. Trump has since been impeached by the House of Representatives and convicted on two articles of impeachment by the Senate, which convicted him of inciting a riot and encouraging an insurrection. The officers were on their way to the Capitol as part of a pro-Trump march when they were attacked. At least one of them was shot and injured. The Capitol riot was not the first time violence had broken out in Washington, DC. Four years ago, a Trump supporter threw a Molotov cocktail in the House of Representatives. In all, there were at least 25 previous incidents in Washington over the course of the Trump administration, the Wall Street Journal reports. The letter was signed by all eight members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who signed a statement condemning the January 6, 2021 riot at the Capitol building in Washington, DC. The statement was signed by all eight members and they describe the January 6, 2021 riot as a direct assault on the U.S. Congress, the Capitol building, and the constitutional process. They warned that the rights of freedom of speech and assembly do not justify violence, sedition, and insurrection, and that those who impeded Joe Biden's inauguration had to be prosecuted. In the statement, the military leaders said: "We are aware of our responsibility to our fellow citizens, our military, and our country. We are fully committed to upholding the Constitution." The Joint Chiefs signed a statement on January 13 condemning the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot and calling for prosecutors to "act immediately to hold those responsible for this heinous act accountable." "We are aware of our responsibility to our fellow citizens, our military, and our country. We are fully committed to upholding the Constitution," the joint chiefs wrote. "We are confident that the process of law and order will restore order to the Capitol building and to Washington, D.C. as soon as it is necessary."

Citi mistakenly sent $900 million to a client's creditors instead of $7.8 million in 2009. In a ruling by a judge, Citi was deemed negligent for their software's mistakes. The judge called the mistake a 'Human error' and noted that design errors are commonplace in software, which leads to costly mistakes over time. Haley Joel Osment, star of the horror film 'Rust', and Alec Baldwin have been charged with second-degree murder in the shooting of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins, while Joel Souza was injured, officials said Tuesday. The Hollywood Reporter reports that Osment, 48, and Baldwin, 49, were booked at the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Office around 4:30 p.m. on Monday after being indicted by a grand jury earlier that day. Both men have been released on bail. Hutchins, 27, was fatally shot and Souza was wounded as they prepared to photograph a scene for "Rust," a new horror film being produced by Paramount Pictures. The film is scheduled for release in theaters in February. Hutchins' family said in a statement that she was a member of the film's crew and a "motivated, kind, and enthusiastic person" who was "kind to everyone, especially her friends and family." The incident occurred as the crew of "Rust" were preparing to shoot an outdoor scene for part of the film, according to Los Angeles County sheriff's officials, who are still investigating the shooting.

The COVID-19 vaccines have not yet reached teens and young children as their parents are wary about giving them the shot. Only 16% of parents of children ages 5 to 11 say their child has been vaccinated, with another 13% planning to do so 'right away', according to a new survey from KidsFirst Foundation (KFF). The pandemic is impacting parents of all ages in unprecedented ways. About half of parents of 12-17 year-olds report their teen has been vaccinated, KFF says. But the report finds that for teens and young children, only one in five parents are sure whether their child will get their shot or not. Parents cite safety and side effects as the primary reasons they are hesitant to give their children the vaccination, KFF says. Parents also express concerns over barriers to vaccination, including cost and transportation, health insurance coverage, lack of access, and lack of knowledge. As a result, parents are delaying vaccination for their children and delaying getting their own vaccinations, the report says. A new study from KidsFirst Foundation finds only 16% of parents of children ages 5 to 11 say their child has been vaccinated, and 13% plan to do so 'right away' The pandemic is impacting parents of all ages in unprecedented ways. KidsFirst Foundation found that half of parents of 12-17 year-olds report their teen has been vaccinated. However, only 16% of parents of children ages 5 to 11 say their child has been vaccinated, 13% plan to do so 'right away' and nearly three in 10 say they will 'definitely not' get their child vaccinated for COVID-19. Hispanic, Black, and lower-income parents express more concern over access barriers to vaccinating their children. Vaccine uptake among teenagers has stalled with less than half of parents of 12-17 year-olds reporting that their teen has been vaccinated, the report says. The survey finds that for teens and young children, only one in five parents are sure whether their child will get their shot or not, and they cite safety and side effects as the primary reasons they are hesitant to give their children the vaccination. Parents also express concerns over barriers to vaccination, including cost and transportation, health insurance coverage, lack of access, and lack of knowledge. As a result, they are delaying vaccination for their children and delaying getting their own vaccinations, the report says. Only 16% of parents of children ages 5 to 11 say their child has been vaccinated, and 13% plan to do so 'right away' while another 13% plan to get the vaccine 'as soon as possible'.

This is a Call to Action for health ministers to give priority consideration to the unique health problems caused by HIV, while also focusing attention to the impact of COVID-19 on those with advanced HIV. Dr Tulio de Oliveira is a journalist for Nature.com who is writing this article as part of his work reporting on the global health crisis. What is the message? People with HIV and other comorbidities should be prioritised for vaccination against COVID-19. What does this mean? This means that people with HIV should be entitled to priority for vaccination, and access to free treatment should be increased and expanded to ensure that people with HIV and other comorbidities are treated as they should be. Please consider signing the letter to urge health ministers to do so. People with HIV should be entitled to priority for vaccination, and access to free treatment should be increased and expanded to ensure that people with HIV and other comorbidities are treated as they should be. This is a Call to Action for health ministers to give priority consideration to these unique health problems caused by HIV. HIV is a chronic, progressive and life-threatening infection that takes a serious toll on those who are infected, but there is no known cure. Therefore, effective treatment is necessary to reduce viral load, which in turn helps to keep the virus from replicating within people with HIV. This in turn reduces the risk of transmitting the infection to others, especially those who are most vulnerable, like children and pregnant women, and it is the most effective way of preventing HIV transmission to others. This can be done through treatment and access to antiretroviral therapy (ART), which, according to World Health Organization (WHO) estimates has saved more than 3 million lives since its introduction in 1996. HIV can be treated and controlled with ART and HIV drugs are easily available and are free in many countries. Unfortunately, in 2020, the number of people with access to HIV drugs was at a critically low level, causing the WHO to urge all governments to urgently increase treatment coverage in those with HIV. In fact, the latest figures from UNAIDS revealed that treatment coverage for people living with HIV (PLHIV) in low-and middle-income countries has fallen by more than 10% since 2017. Some of the most worrying factors that threaten the health of people with HIV, including those living in the United States, are the lack of access to ART and lack of prevention, which is due to a lack of access to HIV drugs. Facebook is dropping its facial recognition system after a five-year, $850 million acquisition, the tech company announced on Thursday. Facebook faces $850 million fine from FTC . Facebook users are being told to tag their photos going forward . Facebook has a database of identified photos that is about the size of a university library . Facebook is dropping facial recognition in a decision that follows a five-year legal and financial back-and-forth between Facebook and regulators . Facebook users are told to look to their phones to tag photos going forward . Nearly a third of Facebook users have facial recognition features enabled and the company says about 1 billion people have access to the technology . Facial recognition, a controversial tech tool used by police and surveillance firms, has long been used by Facebook on its mobile users. Now, the social media firm has confirmed it will shut down the facial recognition system after its acquisition of the Cambridge Analytica scandal-hit data firm. In an announcement on Thursday Facebook said the system will no longer be in use. It added that it had been discontinued after five years, with no timetable for when it would be replaced. The announcement comes after the company was hit by a $850 million fine from the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and a $650 million legal settlement with Illinois residents in which it agreed to pay compensation for the company's use of their data. However, the decision by Facebook follows a five-year legal and financial back-and-forth with regulators and is not entirely surprising. Facial recognition has long been used by Facebook on its mobile users . Facial recognition has been used by Facebook since 2012 . In a blog post, Facebook said the system would continue to work in a number of ways. The firm's head of product, Reuben Rogers, said the system would "continue to be used as an extra layer of authentication" on Facebook. In a statement, Facebook said: 'FACEBOOK will no longer use the technology to automatically identify people in user photos, videos, or other media. 'It will continue to be used as an extra layer of authentication on mobile devices and will continue to be used in our advertising products and for other purposes in the future, but will no longer be used to automatically identify people in photos.' Facial recognition, or face recognition, has long been used by firms such as police and surveillance firms as well as companies like Facebook. Facial recognition has also come under scrutiny in the UK after a woman was raped and murdered, and accused by the police of being a serial killer. Suez Canal Authority Chairman Osama Rabie has called on the Egyptian government to pay up to $1 billion compensation for the shutdown of the Suez Canal and the resulting international trade disruption . Mr Rabie said the amount would be equivalent to $9 billion per day of the shutdown . He is seeking a compensation payment from the Egyptian government, the company says . The Ever Given, a container ship that became stuck in the Suez Canal, caused a disruption of international trade that cost $9 billion per day in lost revenue . The canal is expected to be repaired in six to nine weeks . The Ever Given had to be refloated after becoming stuck in the Suez Canal in April 2012 . Suez Canal Authority chairman Osama Rabie is seeking a compensation payment from the Egyptian government . Last week, a maritime court ordered that the container ship should be repaired in three weeks and sent back to the Suez Canal by the end of the week . The Ever Given, a 200,000 ton mega-container carrier, was refloated six days after becoming stuck .

Photography: Anthony Rodriguez The cinematographer who made "Rust" lost her life on the set of her most recent film when a prop gun containing a live round exploded while the camera was on.

Hutchins, 43, was killed when she was accidentally shot by an unbalanced prop gun loaded with a live round. She had been on the set as part of a test of the production's new prop gun, the result of years of development by Halyna Hutchins and fellow cinematographer Olia Oparina.

Hutchins had been shot seven times, including in the head, and lost consciousness as she was rushed to a hospital, where she was pronounced dead.

The American Film Institute (AFI), a nonprofit organization, established a scholarship fund for women cinematographers in her memory. In the six months since the shooting, the fund has raised $25,000, which is more than double the amount needed to award a scholarship.

"I've been close to Hutchins on and off film sets for the last 10 years," Oparina told WABC News in New York. "She was a wonderful person to work with, and I know how much she touched the hearts of the people she worked with and affected through her positive approach to life."

CNN anchors Chris Cuomo and Don Lemon are gearing up to host a new weekly podcast that's supposed to be unscripted, honest and unapologetic -- just like the conversations they're having in their primetime talk shows. They decided to call it The Handoff, and they aren't going to stop talking about what's happening in the media world and how they both feel about it. The Handoff, Chris Cuomo and Don Lemon will be doing a weekly podcast this fall . The Handoff will be a weekly podcast and available with a subscription to the CNN channel on Apple Podcasts . Their on-air banter, including a discussion about Rick Santorum's offensive remarks, has previously made news . By . Matt Mullenberger . Last updated at 8:21 PM on March 10, 2015 . Chris Cuomo and Don Lemon are known for their on-air banter, and now the duo is launching a new weekly podcast that will be completely unscripted, honest and unapologetic just like the conversations they're having on their primetime talk shows, reports the Hollywood Reporter. The Handoff, a name based on their own spontaneous 'handoff' conversations between Cuomo's and Lemon's respective shows, will be available on Apple Podcasts as a weekly podcast beginning October 1st. The show will feature a mix of guests and their own original material, according to a statement from CNN. "This is a show about us talking about what we want and don't want to talk about in our shows," Lemon said in a press release. "It's a place to talk about how things have affected us, how we feel about these issues and how we think the media is treating them. It'll be about what really is on the tip of every news editor's tongue." The show will begin on Sunday, October 1st, on Apple Podcasts, the Hollywood Reporter reported. Lemon says The Handoff will be "a place to talk about how things have affected us, how we feel about these issues and how we think the media is treating them" and features "a mix of guests and our own original material." The show will initially air on Apple Podcasts, the Hollywood Reporter reported . For more information on Chris Cuomo and Don Lemon, check out their official websites . Tweet with a location

Ever Given shipping container ship is stuck in Suez Canal The Ever Given container ship has become the focus of international attention due to its size and its predicament. By Mark Avery, director of education and research for Atlantictech.com

Ever Given ship is stuck in Suez Canal

Ever Given is longer than the Empire State Building

In an industry where there is a critical shortage of space, Ever Given has come to symbolize an invisible infrastructure of global capital, supply chains and infrastructure that needs to be more transparent, more collaborative, and more open to the world.

Starting on Wednesday, August 3, 2021, The Guardian will host a series of articles exploring the challenges, pitfalls, opportunities and complexities of the Ever Given container ship. It's been a month since one of the largest container ships to ever enter the Suez Canal went awol. The ship, operated by Evergreen, was in the water for more than two weeks and is currently the biggest container ship ever to get stuck in a canal, with a diameter that is smaller than a football field. Scroll down for video

The size of the container ship is mind-blowing, and the fact that the ship has been stuck in a canal for so long makes it even more spectacular. Ever Given's predicament has highlighted the normally invisible infrastructure of global capital and supply chains. It is both an indictment of our capitalist economy and a call to greater transparency and collaboration, as the Guardian's Mark Avery explains. Ever Given is longer than the Empire State Building, the largest building ever built and the world's tallest building, according to CNN. It's also longer than the Statue of Liberty and nearly twice the size of the Eiffel Tower. The Ever Given has become a symbol of global logistics and capitalism, with memes and global attention focused on the ship itself. It has become an instant symbol for something bigger and more important than the Suez Canal: the global shipping industry as a whole.
